S100A8/A9, for instance, promotes chemotaxis and pro-inflammatory gene expression via ERK/Akt pathways. - Divaza's Influence: Modulation dampens this, potentially shifting macrophages toward a less inflammatory phenotype. This is inferred from broader S100 modulation studies, though specific Divaza data is limited. - Neutrophils: S100A8/A9 constitutes ~60% of neutrophil cytoplasmic protein and enhances phagocytosis, reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and NETosis (neutrophil extracellular traps formation). Phosphorylated S100A8/A9 stimulates further cytokine/chemokine release. - Divaza's Influence: Anti-S100 may reduce neutrophil hyperactivation in inflammatory contexts, though direct evidence in Divaza is not extensive. 3. Receptor-Mediated Interactions: - S100 proteins bind to receptors like TLR-4 (Toll-like receptor 4), RAGE (Receptor for Advanced Glycation End-products), G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), and scavenger receptors (e.g., heparin sulfate proteoglycans). - TLR-4 activation by S100 induces NF-κB and AP-1 pathways, leading to pro-inflammatory cascades. - RAGE binding promotes cell migration, cytokine expression, and inflammation amplification. - Divaza's Influence: Anti-S100 interferes with these interactions, reducing downstream signaling. For instance, blocking S100-TLR-4 binding (as seen with S100 inhibitors like paquinimod in related models) could mitigate cytokine storms, though this is extrapolated to Divaza's mechanism. 4. Roles in Inflammation and Specific Immune Responses: - Pro-Inflammatory Amplification: S100 proteins drive cytokine storms, immune cell recruitment, and tissue remodeling (e.g., via matrix metalloproteinases - MMPs and cell adhesion molecules - CAMs). They are elevated in autoimmune diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis), atherosclerosis, and infections like COVID-19, where S100A8/A9 correlates with severity and acts as a prognostic marker. - Divaza's Influence: In the experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE) model—a rodent model of multiple sclerosis (an autoimmune CNS disease)—release-active anti-S100 (as in Divaza) enhanced the disease latency period, reduced peak intensity, and improved overall outcomes. This suggests suppression of pathological T-cell mediated inflammation and demyelination, indicating immunomodulatory effects on adaptive immunity in the CNS. - Antimicrobial Activity: S100 proteins act as antimicrobial peptides by destabilizing pathogen membranes and sequestering essential metals (e.g., Zn, Fe, Mn) to starve bacteria (e.g., E. coli, S. aureus, H. pylori). - Divaza's Influence: No direct antimicrobial effects reported for Divaza, but modulation of S100 could indirectly support innate immune defenses in CNS infections. - Autoimmune and Neuroinflammatory Modulation: In models of brain injury or ischemia, S100 exacerbates inflammation; anti-S100 reduces this, promoting neuroprotection. - Divaza's Influence: Clinical trials show Divaza stabilizes cognitive function in cerebral atherosclerosis, partly by reducing asthenia and anxiety linked to low-grade neuroinflammation. Overall Implications and Limitations - Net Effect: These interactions generally lead to anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective outcomes in the CNS, making Divaza useful for conditions involving neuroimmune dysregulation (e.g., chronic ischemia, mild cognitive impairment). It appears to balance immune responses without causing immunosuppression, as no increased infection risk is reported in studies. - Evidence Base: Most data come from Russian preclinical studies (e.g., EAE model) and limited clinical trials. S100's immune roles are well-established, but Divaza's ultra-diluted nature means effects are subtle and mechanism-specific (e.g., via protein conformation changes rather than blockade). No major systemic immune effects (e.g., on peripheral lymphocytes) are documented; focus is CNS-centric. - Safety: Divaza is well-tolerated, with no reported immune-related adverse events like hypersensitivity or autoimmunity exacerbation. For personalized advice, consult a healthcare provider, as individual responses may vary.

title: Edaravone
content: Pharmacological Actions of Edaravone (CAS 89-25-8) Edaravone is primarily a free radical scavenger and neuroprotective agent approved for treating amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in regions like the US, Canada, and Japan, and for acute ischemic stroke in Japan. Its actions stem from antioxidant properties, targeting oxidative stress implicated in neuronal damage. Below is a comprehensive list of its pharmacological actions based on available data, including mechanisms and any quantitative values where reported (e.g., from clinical studies, PK models, or in vitro/in vivo assays). Quantitative "values" for influence are limited, as most data is qualitative or from disease-specific outcomes (e.g., functional scores in trials). Where possible, I've included metrics like inhibition rates, exposure levels, or efficacy measures to illustrate influence. I've provided as many values as available from reliable sources. 1. Free Radical Scavenging - Description/Influence: Edaravone scavenges reactive oxygen species (ROS), including hydroxyl radicals (•OH) and peroxynitrite (ONOO⁻), preventing oxidative damage to lipids, proteins, and DNA. This reduces neuronal cell death in conditions like ALS and ischemia. - Quantitative Values: - Scavenges •OH and ONOO⁻ radicals effectively in vitro, with no effect on superoxide (O₂⁻) production. - In animal models of brain ischemia, it suppresses ROS-induced inflammatory oxidative stress post-reperfusion. - In human ALS trials (e.g., 6-month study with 137 participants), edaravone (60 mg IV) reduced decline in ALS Functional Rating Scale-Revised (ALSFRS-R) score by ~2.49 points vs. placebo (p=0.0013), indicating delayed functional loss due to ROS scavenging. - Time-related influence: Onset of radical scavenging is rapid (Tmax 0.5-1 hour post-dose), with effects lasting aligned to half-life (4.5-9 hours). 2. Antioxidant Activity - Description/Influence: Inhibits lipid peroxidation and non-enzymatic peroxidation, protecting cell membranes from oxidative stress. This ameliorates neuronal damage in ischemia and ALS by limiting extent of cell death. - Quantitative Values: - Inhibits lipid peroxidation induced by lipid peroxides in endothelial cells (in vitro). - In rat models, oral doses (30-300 mg) reduce markers of oxidative stress (e.g., malondialdehyde levels) dose-dependently. - In stroke models, it suppresses reperfusion injury, improving recovery scores in humans post-thrombolysis (e.g., reduced infarct size in animal studies by 20-50%). - Time-related influence: Peak antioxidant effects correlate with Cmax (1656 ng/mL oral, 1253 ng/mL IV), decaying over half-life. 3. Neuroprotective Effects - Description/Influence: Protects neurons from oxidative stress-induced death, delaying disease progression in ALS and reducing infarct size in stroke. It crosses the blood-brain barrier to exert direct effects. - Quantitative Values: - In ALS, slows motor neuron death; 6-month trial showed less decline in daily functioning (ALSFRS-R difference: 2.49 points). - In ischemic stroke animal models, reduces neuronal damage by inhibiting endothelial injury. - Upregulates Bcl-2 (apoptosis regulator) in humans, reducing apoptosis by ~30-50% in in vitro neuronal cultures exposed to oxidative stress. - In rat brain ischemia, ameliorates damage with ED50-like values around 3-10 mg/kg IV. - Time-related influence: Neuroprotection builds with repeated dosing (e.g., 14-day cycles), with plasma exposure (AUC 0-∞ ~800-1600 ng·h/mL at therapeutic doses) correlating to reduced neuronal loss over 24-48 weeks. 4. Anti-Apoptotic Activity - Description/Influence: Inhibits programmed cell death in neurons by reducing ROS-mediated apoptosis, particularly in ALS and stroke. - Quantitative Values: - Blocks apoptosis in glutamate-exposed neuronal cultures (in vitro IC50 ~10-50 μM). - In ALS models, prevents motor neuron apoptosis caused by oxidative stress, with efficacy in trials showing preserved function (e.g., 33% less decline in ALSFRS-R over 24 weeks). - Time-related influence: Effects peak at Tmax, sustained for duration of exposure (half-life 4.5-9 hours). 5. Anti-Inflammatory Effects - Description/Influence: Suppresses proinflammatory responses, including neutrophil activation and expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) and neuronal NOS (nNOS), reducing inflammation in ischemic brain tissue. - Quantitative Values: - Inhibits neutrophil activation in vitro, reducing inflammatory markers post-ischemia. - In animal models, suppresses iNOS/nNOS expression by 20-40%, ameliorating ROS-induced inflammation after reperfusion. - In human stroke studies, reduces post-ischemic inflammation, contributing to better recovery (e.g., improved modified Rankin Scale scores). - Time-related influence: Anti-inflammatory effects observed within 1-2 hours post-infusion, aligning with rapid absorption. 6. Inhibition of Matrix Metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) - Description/Influence: Inhibits MMP-9-related brain hemorrhage, particularly in thrombolysis-treated stroke, by stabilizing blood-brain barrier. - Quantitative Values: - In rat models treated with tPA, inhibits MMP-9 activity, reducing hemorrhage risk by ~50%. - No specific human quantitative data, but supports use in stroke to prevent complications. - Time-related influence: Acute effect within Tmax window. 7. Other Actions (Less Primary) - Prevents endothelial cell damage and suppresses reperfusion injury in stroke models. - Potential inhibition of glutamate toxicity in neuronal cultures. These actions primarily influence by reducing oxidative burden, with cumulative effects in chronic use (e.g., ALS). Quantitative influence is often measured via disease outcomes (e.g., ALSFRS-R scores) rather than direct action metrics, as edaravone's exact mechanism in ALS remains partially unclear. Half-Life - Parent Compound (Edaravone): Mean terminal elimination half-life is 4.5-9.75 hours (IV or oral). Commonly reported as 4.5-6 hours in most studies. - Metabolites: Sulfate and glucuronide conjugates have half-lives of 2-3 hours (up to 3-6.4 hours in some reports). - Variations: Slightly longer (up to 9.75 hours) after oral administration due to absorption dynamics; 1-2 hours in rat IV studies (preclinical). Bioavailabilities by Route - Intravenous (IV): 100% (complete bioavailability as directly infused). - Oral: Absolute bioavailability ~57-60% (due to first-pass metabolism via UGT enzymes and sulfotransferases). Nonlinear pharmacokinetics observed over 30-300 mg doses, with higher doses showing disproportionate increases in Cmax and AUC. - Food effect: High-fat meal reduces Cmax and AUC by ~20-30%. - In bioequivalence studies, 105 mg oral suspension achieves equivalent AUC to 60 mg IV, despite lower bioavailability. - Other Routes: No data on subcutaneous, intramuscular, or topical; primarily IV and oral. Crosses blood-brain barrier readily (Vd indicates brain distribution). Dosages Dosages vary by indication and route. Edaravone is cycled in ALS to minimize exposure while maintaining efficacy. Safe range is based on clinical trials (up to 300 mg tested orally, but approved doses are lower); toxicity is low (oral LD50 in rats: 1915 mg/kg). Minimum effective dose is indication-specific, derived from trials. For ALS (Approved in US, Japan, Canada): - IV (Radicava): 60 mg infused over 60 minutes once daily. - Cycle: Initial: 14 consecutive days, then 14 days off. Subsequent: 10 days on within 28-day cycles. - Minimum effective: 60 mg (trial dose; lower not established for efficacy). - Safe range: 60 mg daily (no upper limit defined, but trials up to 60 mg); adjust for renal/hepatic impairment if needed. - Oral Suspension (Radicava ORS, 105 mg/5 mL): 105 mg (5 mL) once daily, taken after overnight fast (or via feeding tube). - Cycle: Same as IV (14 days on initial, then 10/28 days). - Minimum effective: ~100-105 mg (equivalent to 60 mg IV based on AUC). - Safe range: 105 mg daily; trials tested 30-300 mg with good tolerability (no accumulation with repeated dosing). Higher doses (e.g., 300 mg) show nonlinear PK but remain safe in healthy adults. For Acute Ischemic Stroke (Approved in Japan): - IV: 30 mg twice daily (total 60 mg/day) infused over 30 minutes each, for up to 14 days. - Minimum effective: 30 mg/dose (based on stroke trials showing reduced infarct size). - Safe range: 60 mg/day; used acutely, with monitoring for hypersensitivity. General Safety and Toxicity: - No established maximum tolerated dose in humans, but single oral doses up to 300 mg were safe in PK studies (adverse events: mild, e.g., headache, bruising in 2-10% more than placebo). - Overdose: Limited data; supportive care recommended. - Adjustments: No dose change for mild renal/hepatic impairment; caution in severe cases. For more values, edaravone shows dose-proportional increases in exposure (AUC, Cmax) at lower doses (20-60 mg IV), but nonlinear at higher oral ranges. Plasma protein binding: 92%. Clearance: 35.9 L/h IV, 67.9 L/h oral. No drug accumulation with daily dosing.

title: Eosinophilia
content: Having 1.24 G/L of eosinophils, which is above the reference range of 0.05–0.60 G/L, indicates eosinophilia, a condition characterized by an elevated number of eosinophils in the blood. Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell involved in the immune response, particularly in allergic reactions and parasitic infections. Possible Causes of Eosinophilia: 1. Allergic Disorders: Allergic rhinitis (hay fever) Asthma Eczema or atopic dermatitis Drug reactions 2. Parasitic Infections: Intestinal worms (helminths) Tissue-invasive parasites (e.g., schistosomiasis or trichinosis) 3. Autoimmune and Inflammatory Conditions: Eosinophilic esophagitis or gastroenteritis Vasculitis (e.g., eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) Certain forms of arthritis 4. Infections: Fungal or certain bacterial infections 5. Blood Disorders: Leukemia or other blood cancers Hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES) 6. Other Causes: Endocrine disorders (e.g., adrenal insufficiency) Certain toxins or environmental exposures Next Steps: 1. Consult Your Doctor: Elevated eosinophil levels require further evaluation to identify the underlying cause. Your doctor will take a thorough history, conduct a physical exam, and potentially order more tests. 2. Additional Tests: Complete blood count (CBC) with differential Blood smear Parasite stool examination Allergy testing Imaging or biopsy (if an organ-specific issue is suspected) 3. Treatment: The treatment depends on the cause: Allergies: Anti-allergic medications like antihistamines or corticosteroids. Parasitic infections: Antiparasitic drugs. Chronic conditions: Specialized treatment plans for diseases like autoimmune disorders or hypereosinophilic syndrome. It's essential to address the root cause rather than focusing solely on the elevated eosinophil count.

title: Essential Forte
content: Active Ingredients in Essentiale Forte Essentiale Forte contains essential phospholipids (EPL) derived from soybeans, primarily consisting of polyunsaturated phosphatidylcholine (PPC) at 300 mg per capsule. The key component is 1,2-dilinoleoylphosphatidylcholine (DLPC), which makes up up to 52% of the PPC. Other minor components include lysophosphatidylcholine (16%), phosphatidylethanolamine (5%), phosphatidylinositol (0.5%), and traces of phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidic acid, diacylglycerol, and triacylglycerol. The PPC content ranges from 72-96% (3-sn-phosphatidyl)choline across formulations, with high levels of essential fatty acids like linoleic acid. Pharmacological Actions Essential phospholipids exert multiple hepatoprotective effects by integrating into cell membranes, modulating lipid metabolism, and influencing cellular functions. Below is a comprehensive list of actions, their mechanisms of influence, and available data on time to onset (where specified; most effects are observed after chronic use, e.g., 1-3 months of treatment, as acute onset data is limited). Effects are primarily on the liver but can extend systemically. | Pharmacological Action | Mechanism of Influence | Time to Onset/Influence Notes | |------------------------|------------------------|------------------------------| | Hepatoprotective | Protects hepatocytes from toxins (e.g., ethanol, carbon tetrachloride, paracetamol) by stabilizing cell membranes and reducing oxidative damage. Accelerates repair of damaged liver tissue. | Effects on liver enzymes and symptoms (e.g., reduced ALT/AST) visible after 4-12 weeks; preclinical models show acute protection within hours, but clinical onset is 1-3 months. | | Membrane Regeneration and Stabilization | EPL integrates into hepatocyte membranes, restoring integrity and fluidity. Increases membrane phosphatidylcholine content, enhancing permeability and enzymatic activity. | Membrane fluidity increases within 24 hours in vitro; clinical regeneration (e.g., improved histology) after 3 months. | | Antioxidant | Inhibits lipid peroxidation by scavenging free radicals and reducing oxidative stress. DLPC component enhances antioxidant defenses. | Acute in vitro effects within hours; clinical reduction in oxidative markers after 4-8 weeks. | | Anti-inflammatory | Modulates cytokine release and reduces inflammation in liver tissue. Influences membrane-dependent signaling pathways. | Reduction in inflammatory markers (e.g., TNF-alpha) after 4-12 weeks in NAFLD studies. | | Antifibrogenic | Inhibits collagen synthesis and fibrosis progression by suppressing stellate cell activation. | Prevents fibrosis in chronic models; clinical slowdown in fibrosis after 3-6 months. | | Anti-apoptotic | Decreases programmed cell death in hepatocytes by stabilizing membranes and reducing caspase activation. | In vitro reduction in apoptosis (e.g., tamoxifen-induced) within 24-48 hours; clinical hepatocyte survival improves over 1-3 months. | | Lipid-Regulating | Reduces fat deposition in the liver (steatosis) and accelerates lipid elimination. Transfers neutral fats and cholesterol to oxidation sites via HDL. | Steatosis regression on imaging (e.g., ultrasound) after 12 weeks; lipid profile improvements (e.g., reduced triglycerides) after 4-8 weeks. | | Detoxification Enhancement | Improves liver's metabolic and detoxification functions by optimizing enzyme activity (e.g., cytochrome P450). | Enhanced detoxification noted after 1-3 months; preclinical models show improved xenobiotic metabolism within days. | | Regenerative | Stimulates hepatocyte proliferation and metabolic activity, aiding liver recovery in conditions like hepatitis. | Liver regeneration acceleration in models within weeks; clinical symptom relief (e.g., appetite improvement) after 1-4 weeks. | | Choleretic (Mild) | Slightly increases bile production and flow, aiding fat digestion. | Minor effect; onset not well-specified, but contributes to overall lipid regulation over weeks. | | Anti-steatotic | Inhibits fatty liver development by normalizing lipid metabolism and reducing insulin resistance. | Steatosis reduction in 53-71% of patients after 3-6 months. | | Membrane Fluidity Modulation | Alters phospholipid composition to increase fluidity, permeability, and receptor function. | In vitro increase in fluidity within hours; sustains over chronic use. | | Apoptosis-Modulating | Reduces apoptosis via membrane protection and signaling modulation. | Similar to anti-apoptotic; in vitro effects rapid (hours), clinical over months. | | Broncholytic (Minor) | Relaxes bronchial smooth muscle; not primary for liver but noted in screening. | Not relevant for liver use; onset acute in models. | | Antilipemic (Minor) | Lowers serum lipids; secondary to liver effects. | Lipid reductions after 4-12 weeks. | These actions collectively improve subjective symptoms (e.g., appetite loss, right hypochondrium pain), biochemical markers (e.g., liver enzymes), imaging (e.g., reduced steatosis), and histology in liver diseases. No toxicity or significant adverse effects reported, ensuring a high efficacy-to-safety ratio. Pharmacokinetics - Absorption: >90% absorbed in the small intestine after oral administration. Most EPL is cleaved by phospholipase A to 1-acyl-lysophosphatidylcholine, with ~50% reacylated to polyunsaturated phosphatidylcholine during mucosal absorption. - Distribution: Rapidly incorporates into hepatocyte membranes. Peak concentration for choline moiety: 6-24 hours (19.9% of dose). Peak for linoleic acid moiety: 4-12 hours (27.9% of dose). - Metabolism: High bioavailability due to direct membrane integration. No major hepatic metabolism beyond incorporation. - Elimination: Fecal excretion: 2% (choline label), 4.5% (linoleic acid label). Urinary excretion: 6% (choline label), trace (linoleic acid label). Indicates minimal systemic clearance. - Half-Life: - Choline component: 66 hours. - Linoleic acid component: 32 hours. - Bioavailability: - Oral: >90% (primary route; no other routes detailed for Forte capsules, though IV forms exist for other Essentiale variants). - No data on other routes (e.g., IV bioavailability assumed near 100% for injections, but not applicable here). - Factors: High due to phospholipid nature; unaffected by food but taken with meals. Dosages Essentiale Forte is dosed orally, swallowed whole with water during meals. No chewing. Duration is unlimited but recommended for at least 1-3 months for noticeable effects; optimal benefits at 3-6 months. No strict upper safe limit, but adherence to recommended doses is advised due to lack of overdose data. Well-tolerated with no reported toxicity even at high doses in animals (>3750 mg/kg/day, ~100x human dose). | Dosage Type | Dose | Population | Notes | |-------------|------|------------|-------| | Starting/Initial | 2 capsules (600 mg EPL) 3 times daily (total: 1800 mg/day) | Adults and children >12 years (body weight >43 kg) | For acute symptoms or high fat accumulation; not to exceed 6 capsules/day. | | Maintenance | 1 capsule (300 mg EPL) 3 times daily (total: 900 mg/day) | Adults and children >12 years | After initial improvement; reduce from starting dose. | | Liver Health Maintenance | 2 capsules (600 mg EPL) once daily (total: 600 mg/day) | Adults | For general support without disease. | | High-Level Fat Accumulation/Unsatisfied Liver Function | 2 capsules (600 mg EPL) 3 times daily (total: 1800 mg/day) | Adults | Matches starting dose. | | Minimum Effective | 900-1800 mg/day (3-6 capsules) | Adults and children >12 years | Based on clinical studies showing efficacy at 1800 mg/day; lower doses (e.g., 900 mg) effective for maintenance but not initial therapy. | | Safe Range | 600-1800 mg/day (2-6 capsules) | Adults and children >12 years | No upper toxicity threshold defined; animal no-effect dose >3750 mg/kg/day. Not recommended for children <12 years due to insufficient data. | | Double-Strength Variant (Essentiale Forte N 600 mg) | 1 capsule (600 mg EPL) 3 times daily (total: 1800 mg/day) | Adults | Equivalent to standard starting dose but fewer capsules. | Compliance: Take with meals for optimal absorption. Monitor liver function (e.g., enzymes, imaging) monthly. Not for use in pregnancy/breastfeeding (insufficient data). Consult physician for adjustments.

title: Fabomotizole
content: Fabomotizole (also known as afobazole; CAS 173352-21-5, noting the user's provided CAS 173352-21-1 appears to be a minor typo) is a selective anxiolytic drug primarily used in Russia for treating anxiety disorders and adjustment disorders. It is not a benzodiazepine and lacks sedative, hypnotic, or muscle relaxant effects at therapeutic doses. Below, I outline its pharmacological actions based on available data, including any quantitative measures (e.g., binding affinities like Ki values, where known) that indicate potency or influence. These values help illustrate the drug's relative strength in interacting with targets—lower Ki values generally mean higher affinity and potentially stronger influence at that site. I've provided as many values as possible from reliable sources, noting that the mechanism is not fully elucidated and some actions are proposed based on preclinical studies. Pharmacological Actions and Associated Values Fabomotizole's effects stem from interactions with multiple targets, leading to anxiolytic (anti-anxiety) and neuroprotective outcomes without CNS depression. Key actions include: - Sigma-1 receptor (σ1R) agonism/chaperone activity: Acts as a ligand at sigma-1 receptors, enhancing cellular stress responses, modulating calcium signaling, and providing neuroprotection against ischemia, acidosis, and stress. This is considered a primary mechanism for anxiolytic and neuroprotective effects. - Ki = 5.9 µM (moderate affinity; higher doses needed for significant effect). - IC50 = 6.4–13.7 µM (in mouse brain homogenates, varying by strain; indicates inhibition of ligand binding). - Influence: Prevents stress-induced reductions in GABAA receptor benzodiazepine site binding; reduces neuronal calcium overload in ischemia models at 0.3–3 mg/kg (animal doses). Anxiolytic effects in elevated plus maze tests (e.g., increased open-arm time) at 2.5–5 mg/kg in mice are blocked by sigma-1 antagonists like BD-1047 or NE-100. - Monoamine oxidase A (MAO-A) reversible inhibition: Inhibits MAO-A, potentially increasing serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine levels, contributing to mood stabilization and anxiolytic effects. - Ki = 3.6 µM (moderate affinity). - Influence: Reversible, unlike irreversible MAOIs; may enhance serotoninergic tone without strong antidepressant effects. Involved in anti-stress responses but less potent than dedicated MAOIs. - Melatonin receptor type 3 (MT3; also NRH:quinone oxidoreductase 2 or NQO2) antagonism: Antagonizes MT3 receptors, which may modulate oxidative stress and neuroprotection. - Ki = 0.97 µM (high affinity; stronger interaction compared to other targets). - Influence: Contributes to neuroprotective effects; metabolite M-11 (main active metabolite) retains this activity, potentially prolonging some effects. - Melatonin receptor type 1 (MT1) agonism: Agonism at MT1 receptors, possibly influencing sleep-wake cycles and neuroprotection, though affinity is low. - Ki = 160 µM (low affinity; minimal influence at therapeutic doses; some sources report 16 µM, but 160 µM is more consistent across data). - Influence: Suggested role in anxiolytic effects, but weak; may promote nerve growth factor (NGF) and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) release. - GABAergic modulation (indirect): Proposed promotion of GABAA receptor function via sigma-1 interactions, without direct binding to benzodiazepine sites. - No direct Ki/IC50 available (not a direct ligand). - Influence: Enhances GABA signaling under stress; prevents ischemia-induced calcium overload in neurons at 10–100 µM in vitro. - NGF and BDNF release promotion: Stimulates release of neurotrophic factors, supporting neuronal survival and plasticity. - No specific quantitative values (preclinical observations). - Influence: Neuroprotective in stroke models; reduces neuronal death in rat middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) at 0.3–3 mg/kg. - Serotonin receptor involvement (unspecified): Potential indirect effects on serotonin systems, possibly via MAO-A inhibition. - No specific Ki/IC50. - Influence: May contribute to anxiolytic mood effects; not well-quantified. - Other neuroprotective actions: Antimutagenic and antiteratogenic in mice; reduces hyperglycemia and oxidative stress in streptozotocin models. - Effective at 10 mg/kg (animal dose) for reducing malondialdehyde accumulation. - Influence: Broad anti-stress effects; restores dopamine in Parkinson's models (e.g., 6-OHDA-lesioned striatum) at deferred doses. These actions collectively produce anxiolytic effects (e.g., reducing anxiety in generalized anxiety disorder) and neuroprotection (e.g., in ischemia or stress models) without sedation. Potency is generally moderate (micromolar Ki values), requiring multi-target engagement for full effects. Clinical efficacy is seen at 30 mg/day, non-inferior to diazepam (30 mg/day) in trials but with better safety. Half-Life - Elimination half-life: 0.82 ± 0.54 hours (short, necessitating multiple daily doses to maintain levels; no accumulation with repeated dosing). Bioavailabilities - Oral bioavailability: 43.64% (moderate, with pronounced first-pass hepatic metabolism reducing systemic exposure). - No data on other routes (e.g., IV, IM) in standard use; the drug is primarily oral. Preclinical studies may use IP or IV, but human bioavailability for non-oral routes is not established. Extensive hepatic metabolism (via CYP3A4 and CYP2D6) yields inactive metabolites, with renal excretion (~70% as metabolites). Dosages Fabomotizole is typically administered orally in tablets. Doses are based on clinical trials and Russian guidelines (not FDA-evaluated). - Minimum effective dose: 10 mg/day (divided; e.g., 5–10 mg 1–2 times daily), sufficient for mild anxiety in some patients. - Standard/therapeutic range (safe range): 10–30 mg/day, divided into 2–3 doses (e.g., 10 mg three times daily). Used for 2–4 weeks, extendable to 12 weeks under supervision. - Maximum dose without high risks: Up to 60 mg/day (divided; e.g., 20 mg three times daily) in severe cases, per some clinical practices, with monitoring. Exceeding this increases side effect risk without proportional benefit. - LD50 (lethal dose 50%): Not publicly available for humans (rare overdose reports; low toxicity profile). In animal studies (mice/rats), LD50 >1,000 mg/kg (oral/IP), indicating very low acute toxicity. No fatal human overdoses reported; drug has a wide therapeutic index. - When it starts to become too dangerous (estimation): Doses >60–100 mg/day may increase risks of mild-to-moderate side effects (e.g., nausea, headache, dizziness). Overdose symptoms (rare, even at high doses) include drowsiness, GI upset, or allergic reactions; severe toxicity unlikely without co-ingestants. At >200–500 mg (estimation based on animal scaling), potential for pronounced CNS effects or organ strain, but no data on lethal thresholds in humans. Seek medical help for any suspected overdose; supportive care is sufficient due to short half-life. Side effects are mild/rare (e.g., nausea, headache, dizziness, allergic rash; <5% incidence) and resolve quickly. No withdrawal, dependence, or abuse potential. Well-tolerated in trials vs. diazepam. For closed-ended math (e.g., half-life calculations), no specific equations are needed here, but half-life (t1/2 = 0.82 h) means plasma levels halve every ~0.82 hours: after 1 dose, ~50% remains at 0.82 h; ~25% at 1.64 h. Steady-state with TID dosing maintains therapeutic levels.

title: Flupirtine Maleate
content:
Pharmacological Actions of Flupirtine Maleate Flupirtine maleate is a centrally acting non-opioid analgesic with a unique profile. Its primary actions stem from its mechanism as a selective neuronal potassium channel opener (SNEPCO), particularly targeting Kv7 (KCNQ) voltage-gated potassium channels. This leads to neuronal membrane hyperpolarization, reducing excitability and pain signaling. It also has indirect NMDA receptor antagonistic effects (without direct binding) and GABAA receptor modulatory properties, contributing to its effects. Additional actions include antioxidant properties and influences on other channels like GIRK (G-protein-coupled inwardly rectifying potassium channels). Below is a comprehensive list of its pharmacological actions, based on available data from clinical and preclinical studies. | Pharmacological Action | Description and Influence | Quantitative Values (Where Available) | |------------------------|---------------------------|---------------------------------------| | Analgesic (Pain Relief) | Provides relief for acute and chronic pain by stabilizing neuronal membranes, inhibiting nociceptive impulse transmission, and reducing NMDA-mediated calcium influx. Effective for musculoskeletal pain, headaches, postoperative pain, oncology-related pain, dysmenorrhea, and neuropathic pain. Influences by decreasing neuronal hyperexcitability without opioid-like dependence. | - Therapeutic plasma concentration: 1–10 μM (general); 2–6 μM for Kv7 activation.
- Effective dose range in studies: 200–600 mg/day reduces pain scores by >95% in post-marketing surveillance (n=7,806 patients).
- Discriminative effects mediated via alpha-2 adrenergic mechanisms (not opioid or alpha-1).
- NMDA inhibition: Dose-dependent reduction in glutamate-induced Ca++ rise (no specific IC50 reported).
- Analgesic potency: Comparable to pentazocine, dihydrocodeine, paracetamol, or ibuprofen; less than morphine or buprenorphine.
- In low-back pain: 300 mg/day equivalent to tramadol 150 mg/day (randomized double-blind study). | | Muscle Relaxant (Skeletal and Smooth Muscle) | Reduces muscle tension and spasticity by hyperpolarizing motor neurons and inhibiting polysynaptic reflexes (e.g., flexor reflex). Influences conditions like chronic musculoskeletal pain or spasticity without affecting monosynaptic reflexes (e.g., H-reflex). | - Effective in same dose as analgesia (100–400 mg/day).
- Reduces polysynaptic flexor reflex by 2 hours post-200 mg dose (healthy subjects).
- No quantitative potency values like EC50; acts via Kv7 and GIRK channels.
- In cancer-related neuropathic pain: Combined with opioids, reduces pain and improves quality of life (case series, n=10). | | Neuroprotective | Protects neurons from damage by upregulating Bcl-2, increasing glutathione levels, delaying mitochondrial calcium loss, and acting as an antioxidant. Influences by preventing excitotoxicity and oxidative stress in models of energy deprivation or neurotoxic exposure. Potential in neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., improved cognition in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). | - Effective concentration: 2–6 μM (in vitro Kv7 enhancement).
- Bcl-2 upregulation and glutathione increase: Observed in preclinical models.
- Antioxidant effect: 10–100 times higher than therapeutic range (1–10 μM) in some studies.
- No abuse potential in most cases, but tolerance reported individually. | | Anticonvulsant (Potential) | Inhibits sustained neuronal action potential firing and hyperexcitability, potentially useful in seizures. Influences by enhancing Kv7/M-channel activity and GABAA potentiation. | - Effective in preclinical models; human therapeutic range: 1–10 μM.
- Kv7 activation: Inhibits action potential firing (no specific EC50).
- Potentiates GABAA receptors (additive to Kv7 effects). | | Smooth Muscle Relaxant | Relaxes smooth muscles, potentially aiding in dysmenorrhea or other visceral pain. Influences via similar channel-opening mechanisms. | - Limited quantitative data; overlaps with skeletal relaxant effects at 100–600 mg/day. | These actions are interconnected, with the primary influence being neuronal stabilization via potassium efflux and reduced calcium influx, leading to decreased excitability without opioid risks or NSAID gastrointestinal effects. No addictive properties in most studies, but rare abuse cases noted. Hepatotoxicity is a key risk, restricting long-term use. Half-Life The elimination half-life varies by route, population, and formulation: - Average: 6.5 hours (oral administration in healthy adults). - Intravenous: 1.8–8.5 hours. - Rectal: 10.7 hours. - Elderly: 11.2–16.8 hours (average 14 hours). - Moderate renal impairment: 8.7–10.9 hours (average 9.8 hours). - Oral (immediate-release): ~9.6 hours. - After repeated dosing: Steady-state reached in 2 days, no accumulation observed over 28 days (100 mg 3x daily). Bioavailabilities Flupirtine is rapidly absorbed but bioavailability varies: - Oral: 90% (complete absorption from GI tract; reaches peak in 1.6–2 hours). - Rectal: 70% (peak at 5.7 hours). - Immediate-release capsules: ~72%. - Modified-release: ~60% (lower due to formulation). - Absolute bioavailability (vs. IV): 100% for oral, 72.5% for rectal. - No data on other routes like IV bioavailability (assumed 100%). Dosages Dosages are tailored for pain relief, with restrictions due to hepatotoxicity (limited to acute pain ≤2 weeks; monitor liver enzymes; avoid in liver disease or if other analgesics are viable). Start at lowest effective dose. | Category | Recommended Dosage | Details | |----------|--------------------|---------| | Adult Oral | 100–400 mg/day (divided into 3–4 doses; max 600 mg/day). | - Standard: 100 mg capsule 3–4 times daily.
- For moderate-severe acute pain: 300–400 mg/day.
- In studies: 200–600 mg/day (e.g., 100 mg 4x daily common in fibromyalgia trials).
- Immediate-release: 50–100 mg capsules.
- Modified-release: Adjusted for lower bioavailability. | | Adult Rectal | 450–600 mg/day (suppositories). | - 150 mg suppository 3–4 times daily. | | Children | 150–200 mg/day (oral) or 150–250 mg/day (rectal), divided into 3–4 doses. | - For ages where approved; lower in mild renal impairment or elderly. | | Minimum Effective Dose | 100 mg single dose (oral). | - Achieves pain relief in acute settings; plasma Cmax ~0.8–2.0 mg/L at 1.6–2 hours.
- For chronic: Start at 100–200 mg/day. | | Safe Range | 100–600 mg/day (adults); do not exceed 600 mg/day. | - Initiate at lowest dose for efficacy (e.g., 100 mg).
- Elderly/renal impairment: Use lowest dose; monitor transaminases.
- Duration: ≤2 weeks (per 2013 restrictions); withdrawn in some markets (e.g., EU 2018) due to liver injury risks.
- No tolerance in most (up to 1 year), but individual cases reported.
- Overdose risk: Hepatotoxicity; no psychological/motor impairment at therapeutic doses. | For veterinary (e.g., horses): 1 mg/kg IV or 5 mg/kg oral (bioavailability 71.4%), but not relevant to human use.

title: Furosemide
content: Pharmacological Actions of Furosemide Furosemide is a potent loop diuretic primarily used for treating edema, hypertension, and conditions like heart failure or renal disease. Its main mechanism is inhibiting the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter (NKCC2) in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, leading to reduced reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and water. It also affects proximal and distal tubules. Below is a comprehensive list of its pharmacological actions, based on data from sources like DrugBank, StatPearls, and FDA labels. For each, I've included available time course data (onset, peak, and duration) where applicable, focusing on diuretic and related effects. These can vary by route of administration, patient factors (e.g., renal impairment), and dose. Times are averages for standard adult doses (e.g., 20-80 mg oral or IV). - Diuretic Effect (Primary Action: Increased Urinary Excretion of Water, Sodium, Chloride, Potassium): Inhibits electrolyte reabsorption, promoting natriuresis and diuresis. This reduces extracellular fluid volume. - Oral: Onset 30-60 minutes, peak 1-2 hours, duration 6-8 hours. - IV: Onset 5 minutes, peak 20-60 minutes, duration 2 hours. - IM: Onset 10-30 minutes, peak unknown (likely 1-2 hours), duration 4-8 hours. - SUBQ: Onset unknown (likely within 1 hour), peak unknown (median 4-5 hours based on bioavailability studies), duration 8 hours. - Influence: Leads to rapid fluid loss (up to 1-2 liters in responsive patients), but can cause dehydration if excessive. In renal impairment, duration prolongs (up to 24 hours total effect). - Electrolyte Imbalance Induction (Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia, Hypomagnesemia, Hypocalcemia): Increases excretion of potassium, magnesium, and calcium; can cause hyponatremia via water loss. - Time Course: Mirrors diuretic effect (peaks within 1-2 hours post-dose), but cumulative with repeated dosing; effects like hypokalemia may manifest over days/weeks. - Influence: Risk of arrhythmias (e.g., due to low potassium/magnesium), muscle cramps, or metabolic alkalosis (from chloride loss and hydrogen ion shifts). - Venodilation and Preload Reduction: Direct vasodilatory effect on veins, reducing venous return to the heart (beneficial in acute pulmonary edema). - IV: Onset within 5-15 minutes (faster than diuretic effect), peak 30 minutes, duration 2-4 hours. - Influence: Rapid relief of dyspnea in heart failure; lowers pulmonary capillary wedge pressure before significant diuresis occurs. - Antihypertensive Effect: Reduces blood pressure via volume depletion and possible direct vascular effects. - Oral: Onset 1-2 hours, peak 4-6 hours, duration 6-8 hours per dose; full effect may take days with chronic use. - Influence: Lowers systolic/diastolic pressure by 10-20 mmHg in responsive patients; more pronounced in hypertension with edema. - Increased Uric Acid Retention (Hyperuricemia): Competes with uric acid for renal secretion, potentially precipitating gout. - Time Course: Acute rise within hours of dose, peaks 4-6 hours; chronic elevation with repeated use. - Influence: Can exacerbate gout attacks; risk increases with doses >80 mg/day. - Metabolic Effects (e.g., Hyperglycemia, Metabolic Alkalosis): Mild glucose elevation due to hypokalemia; alkalosis from bicarbonate retention. - Time Course: Onset 1-2 hours, peaks with diuretic effect; resolves as drug clears. - Influence: Worsens diabetes control; alkalosis can cause fatigue or confusion. - Ototoxicity (Hearing Loss, Tinnitus): High doses inhibit NKCC1 in the inner ear, causing reversible or permanent damage. - IV (rapid infusion): Onset minutes to hours, peak during infusion, duration variable (often transient, but permanent at >200 mg rapid IV). - Influence: Dose-related; higher risk in renal failure or with aminoglycosides. - Other Minor Actions: Noncompetitive blockade of GABA-A receptors (at high concentrations, potential CNS effects like sedation); increased renal blood flow initially. - Time Course: Not well-defined for these; generally aligns with peak plasma levels (1-2 hours oral, 30 minutes IV). - Influence: Rare clinical relevance except in overdose. Note: In renal or hepatic impairment, all effects prolong due to extended half-life. Maximum diuresis/electrolyte loss is greater than with thiazides but similar to other loop diuretics. Half-Life - Normal renal function: 0.5-2 hours (average 1-1.5 hours). - Renal impairment: Prolonged, up to 9-24 hours in severe cases (e.g., end-stage renal disease). - Hepatic impairment: Doubled (e.g., up to 4-10 hours in cirrhosis). - Neonates/Infants: 1.2-67 hours (highly variable, longer in prematures). - Elderly: Slightly prolonged (e.g., 2-3 hours). Bioavailabilities by Route Bioavailability varies widely due to absorption-limited kinetics and patient factors (e.g., gut edema in heart failure reduces it). - Oral (tablets/solution): 10-100%, average 47-70% (commonly ~50-64%; higher with food, lower in uremia or severe edema). - IV: 100%. - IM: ~100% (similar to IV, but slightly delayed absorption). - SUBQ: 99-112% (nearly complete, based on formulations like Furoscix). - Sublingual: ~59% (slightly higher than oral, but similar kinetics). Dosages Dosages are individualized based on response, condition, and renal function. Titrate to the minimum effective dose to minimize risks like electrolyte loss. Below are guidelines from sources like Drugs.com, Medscape, and FDA labels. All for adults unless noted; pediatrics: 1-2 mg/kg (max 6 mg/kg/day). - Safe Range (General): 20-600 mg/day oral/IV, divided doses. Start low (20-40 mg), increase gradually. Monitor electrolytes, weight, and renal function daily initially. - Minimum Effective Dose: Varies; e.g., 20 mg oral for mild edema/hypertension; 40 mg IV for acute pulmonary edema. In responsive patients, 5-10 mg may suffice initially. - Maximum Without High Risks: Up to 600 mg/day in severe/refractory cases (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, severe heart failure), but only under close monitoring. Individual doses: Max 200 mg IV per dose. Risks (dehydration, ototoxicity) rise >80-160 mg/day or with rapid IV infusion. - LD50 (Lethal Dose 50%): No human data (ethical reasons). Animal data: Oral rat 2600 mg/kg; IP rat 800 mg/kg; SC rat 4600 mg/kg. Human lowest published toxic dose (TDLo): 6.25 mg/kg (female, oral). Overdose threshold not fixed, but symptoms (severe hypotension, shock, renal failure) can start at 200-500 mg in sensitive patients. - When It Becomes Too Dangerous: No exact threshold, but risks escalate at >200 mg single IV dose (ototoxicity) or >600 mg/day chronic (electrolyte imbalances, gout, renal damage). Dangerous in renal failure (prolonged effects), dehydration, or with ototoxic drugs. Overdose: Dehydration/electrolyte loss leads to shock; treat supportively (fluids, electrolytes). Signs of danger: Urine output >1 mL/kg/h unresponsive, severe hypokalemia (<3 mEq/L), or hypotension. Always consult a healthcare provider for personalized dosing, as furosemide can interact with many drugs (e.g., NSAIDs reduce efficacy, digoxin increases arrhythmia risk with hypokalemia).

title: Genferon 1
content: GENFERON® suppositories, containing Interferon alfa-2b, Benzocaine, and Taurine, are designed for both local and systemic immunomodulatory, antiviral, and antibacterial effects. The interferon component is absorbed through the mucous membranes into surrounding tissues and the lymphatic system, allowing it to exert effects beyond the site of administration. However, the extent of systemic action (i.e., affecting the whole body) depends on the route: - Rectal administration: Provides high bioavailability (over 80%), leading to pronounced systemic immunomodulatory effects alongside local action. - Vaginal administration: Primarily achieves strong local effects at the infection site, with minimal systemic absorption due to the vaginal mucosa's low uptake capacity. Benzocaine acts as a local anesthetic, reducing permeability of cell membranes and blocking nerve impulses mainly at the insertion site, while Taurine supports anti-inflammatory and regenerative effects locally. Peak serum interferon levels occur about 5 hours after use, but decline within 12 hours, often requiring repeated dosing for sustained effects. Overall, while not exclusively systemic, the drug does impact the entire body, particularly via rectal use in treatments like urogenital infections or viral conditions.

title: Genferon 2
content: For rectal administration of GENFERON® suppositories, the interferon alfa-2b component exhibits high bioavailability, exceeding 80%, which allows it to be absorbed into the systemic circulation and exert pronounced immunomodulatory effects throughout the body. This means over 80% of the interferon dose reaches the bloodstream unchanged, contributing to whole-body antiviral and immune responses, in addition to local effects at the administration site. Peak serum concentrations are typically achieved around 5 hours post-administration, with an elimination half-life of about 12 hours, supporting twice-daily dosing for sustained systemic activity. Benzocaine primarily provides local anesthetic effects with minimal systemic absorption, while taurine aids in local anti-inflammatory and regenerative actions, so the overall "whole-body" impact is driven predominantly by the interferon's >80% systemic bioavailability.

title: Gepatamin
content: Here’s what can be said about Gepatamin based on currently available scientific and product-label information — with a clear emphasis on limitations, because Gepatamin is not an approved pharmaceutical drug with well-characterized pharmacological parameters in the medical literature. Instead, it’s marketed in many places (especially Russia/Eastern Europe) as a dietary supplement / liver “bioregulator” / hepatoprotective peptide complex. There are no authoritative peer–reviewed pharmacokinetic, pharmacodynamic, toxicology, LD₅₀, or dose-response data in standard scientific databases. ([Цитамины][1]) --- 🧪 What Gepatamin Is Gepatamin is sold as a complex of proteins / peptides and nucleoproteins derived from bovine liver, with claims of selective activity on liver hepatocytes — purportedly supporting regeneration and metabolic normalization of the liver. It’s often described as hepatoprotective and bioregulatory rather than a defined drug with specific receptors or molecular mechanisms. ([Цитамины][1]) 👉 Important: This product is generally classified as a dietary supplement (“БАД”) rather than an approved medicine in many markets, meaning it is not regulated to the same pharmacological standards as licensed drugs. ([Цитамины][1]) --- ⚙️ Claimed Pharmacological Actions The described actions are not well studied in controlled clinical pharmacology and come from product information rather than rigorous trials: Hepatoprotective / bioregulatory for hepatocytes — claimed to accelerate repair and restore function. ([Цитамины][1]) Normalization of hepatocyte metabolism and enzymatic activity. ([gorzdrav.org][2]) Stabilization of liver biochemical markers like bilirubin and liver enzymes (reported in unofficial sources). ([Цитамины][1]) > Note: These effects are claimed by sellers and not confirmed by high-quality independent pharmacology studies. There is no established receptor target, enzyme mechanism, or validated animal/human pharmacodynamic model published in peer-reviewed journals. --- 🧬 Pharmacokinetics: Essentially Unknown There is no published pharmacokinetic profile (absorption, distribution, metabolism, elimination) in recognized scientific databases such as PubMed or DrugBank for Gepatamin: Bioavailability (oral or other routes): Not established in medical literature. Half-life (t½): Not known. Peak concentration (Tmax): No data available. Distribution / Vd: No data available. Metabolism pathways: Not characterized. Elimination routes: Not characterized. Because Gepatamin is a peptide/protein complex that presumably breaks down into amino acids, traditional small-molecule PK parameters are not reliably defined. --- 💊 Dosage Information (Claimed, Not Scientifically Verified) Available product information gives recommendations used by manufacturers, not evidence-based therapeutic dosing: Typical suggested dosage: ~1–3 tablets, 2–3 times per day, taken 10–15 minutes before meals for 10–15 days, with possible repeat courses after months. ([Цитамины][1]) Even this recommendation is not from clinical pharmacology studies and should not be taken as a medically validated dose range. --- 🚨 Toxicity, Safety, LD₅₀, Therapeutic Indices There is no authoritative toxicology or LD₅₀ data for Gepatamin in humans or animals found in scientific literature. Because it is a complex mixture of peptides derived from animal tissue, an LD₅₀ (lethal dose 50%) measurement analogous to a defined chemical or drug is not established. Manufacturers claim that the product: Does not accumulate in the body. ([Цитамины][1]) Does not cause withdrawal or classical side effects. ([Цитамины][1]) But again, these are unverified claims on product marketing pages, not clinical safety data. ⚠️ “Too dangerous” thresholds are unknown because there is no rigorous safety evaluation or overdose data available. --- 📌 Scientific Caveats Because Gepatamin is marketed as a dietary supplement/bioregulator, it lacks the following: ✔ Peer-reviewed pharmacodynamic (mechanism) characterization. ✔ Standard pharmacokinetic studies (bioavailability, half-life, Tmax, clearance). ✔ Formal toxicology or LD₅₀ studies. ✔ Regulatory approval by major agencies (FDA/EMA) as a drug. Therefore, the data you’re asking for (exact pharmacological effects, half-life, bioavailability, LD₅₀, toxic thresholds) do not exist in the scientific record for this compound. The available information comes from product descriptions rather than controlled research. --- 🧠 Summary | Parameter | Known / Established | Notes | | ------------------------- | -------------------------------------- | ------------------------ | | Pharmacological Actions | Claimed hepatoprotective/bioregulatory | No validated mechanisms | | Bioavailability | Unknown | No human PK data | | Half-Life | Unknown | Not studied | | Tmax / Cmax | Unknown | Not studied | | Metabolism | Unknown | Likely peptide digestion | | Excretion | Unknown | Not studied | | Therapeutic Dose Range | Product-suggested dosing | Not clinically verified | | LD₅₀ / Toxicity Threshold | Unknown | No toxicology data | --- 🧾 What You Should Know If You’re Considering Use Consult a medical professional before using this product, especially if you have liver disease or take other medications. Because there’s no clinical pharmacology backing, efficacy and safety are not established. Regulatory status and quality control can vary by region and manufacturer. --- If you want, I can help explain how drugs that do have well-characterized liver protective effects (like ursodeoxycholic acid or N-acetylcysteine) work in comparison, with proper pharmacokinetic data. [1]: https://cytamins.ru/catalog/gepatamin/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Гепатамин Классик — средство для восстановления ..." [2]: https://gorzdrav.org/catalog/gepatamin/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Гепатамин инструкция по применению, цена на gepatamin"

title: Glycine 1
content: Pharmacological Actions of Glycine Glycine is a non-essential amino acid with several key pharmacological actions, primarily in the central nervous system (CNS) and periphery. It acts as both an inhibitory neurotransmitter and an excitatory co-agonist, depending on the receptor. - Inhibitory Neurotransmission (via Strychnine-Sensitive Glycine Receptors - GlyRs): Glycine binds to ligand-gated chloride channels (GlyRs) in the spinal cord, brainstem, and other CNS areas, increasing Cl⁻ influx, hyperpolarizing neurons, and reducing excitability. This mediates fast inhibitory signaling, regulating motor control, sensory processing (e.g., pain, hearing), and reflex arcs. - Excitatory Co-Agonism at NMDA Receptors: Glycine binds to the strychnine-insensitive site on NMDA receptors (obligatory co-agonist with glutamate), facilitating receptor activation, Ca²⁺ influx, and enhanced excitatory neurotransmission. This is prominent in the forebrain and supports synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory. - Antispastic Effects: Enhances spinal inhibitory transmission via GlyRs, potentially reducing muscle spasticity. - Antipsychotic Potential: Potentiates NMDA function, which may improve negative symptoms in schizophrenia (adjunctive therapy). - Antioxidant and Anti-Inflammatory Effects: Attenuates neutrophil oxidant production and protects against oxidative stress, hypoxia-reperfusion injury, and inflammation (e.g., in liver or endotoxin models). - Other Effects: Hepatic detoxification (conjugation with toxins for excretion), potential metabolic benefits (e.g., insulin secretion modulation via NMDA in periphery), and indirect roles in sleep improvement or neuroprotection. Pharmacokinetic Parameters - Absorption: Rapidly absorbed from the small intestine via active transport (Na⁺/Cl⁻-dependent transporters). Oral administration shows peak plasma levels ~30 minutes post-ingestion. - Bioavailability: High for oral route (near-complete absorption as an amino acid; studies show significant plasma increases, e.g., ~54% above baseline at 3 g dose). No exact percentage reported in most sources, but considered excellent. - Half-Life (Plasma): Dose-dependent, ranging from 0.43–4.08 hours (26–245 minutes). Increases proportionally with dose (e.g., shorter at low doses, longer at high doses due to saturation of metabolism). - Metabolism: Primarily hepatic; degraded via glycine cleavage system or converted to serine/pyruvate. - Elimination: Renal (as metabolites) and hepatic. - Other: Plasma returns to baseline ~3 hours after oral dosing in studies. Dosage Information Dosages vary by indication and are generally oral (supplements or capsules). Glycine is well-tolerated, but high doses (>15 g/day) may cause mild GI upset (nausea, diarrhea). - General Supplementation/Sleep Improvement: 3–5 g/day (often 3 g before bed for sleep effects). Minimum effective: ~3 g. - Schizophrenia (Adjunctive): 30–60 g/day (or 0.4–0.8 g/kg/day). Minimum effective: Often ~30 g/day in trials. - Antispastic or Other Therapeutic: 2–60 g/day in clinical studies. - Safe Range: Up to 6 g/day well-tolerated for weeks; studies show 90 g/day tolerated short-term. Doses of 1 g/day are very safe; avoid exceeding 60 g/day chronically without monitoring. - Other Routes: IV (in parenteral nutrition or studies), irrigation (surgical). No standard oral bioavailability differences vs. other routes noted. These values are from clinical studies and reviews; individual responses vary. Consult a healthcare provider for personalized use, especially at high doses.

title: Glycine 2
content: Glycine (aminoacetic acid) is a non-essential amino acid that serves endogenous roles but exhibits pharmacological effects primarily when supplemented (orally, IV, or otherwise), acting via specific receptors and metabolic pathways. Key Pharmacological Actions and Associated Time Parameters Glycine’s actions stem from: - Strychnine-sensitive glycine receptors (GlyRs): Ligand-gated Cl⁻ channels (α1–α4 + β subunits), causing hyperpolarization/inhibition (CNS: spinal cord/brainstem/retina for motor/sensory/pain/reflex control; immune cells for anti-inflammatory effects). Effective channel opening ~1–3 mM (far above normal plasma ~200–300 µM). - Strychnine-insensitive glycine site on NMDA receptors: Co-agonist with glutamate, enhancing excitatory signaling (supports NMDA hypofunction hypothesis in schizophrenia negative symptoms/cognition). - Other: GPRC6A (GPCR), transporters; precursor for glutathione (antioxidant), creatine; one-carbon metabolism; cytoprotection (e.g., blocks plasma membrane pores, attenuates neutrophils/ROS in ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI), endotoxemia, liver injury). Specific actions with time values (where data exist; many are plasma PK-driven or chronic; synaptic effects are fast but supplemental systemic effects lag absorption/brain entry): 1. Inhibitory neurotransmission/antispastic (GlyR-mediated): - Synaptic: Milliseconds–seconds (IPSP via Cl⁻ influx). - Supplemental (antispastic/antinociceptive potential): Plasma peak ~30 min post-oral (1 g dose → +54% plasma glycine); effects duration aligns with elevated levels (~3 h return to baseline for low doses). Higher doses prolong via intracellular accumulation. 2. NMDA co-agonism/antipsychotic (negative symptoms in schizophrenia, cognition): - Acute brain/CSF increase: Oral/IV raises levels; plasma Tmax ~0.5–4 h (formulation-dependent), brain entry documented. - Clinical effects: Onset over weeks (6–8 weeks in trials at 0.4–0.8 g/kg/day); no acute single-dose data for symptoms. Improves negative symptoms (e.g., ~30% reduction in PANSS negative subscale in some trials), cognition/alertness in some studies. - Duration: Requires chronic dosing; effects wane post-discontinuation. 3. Anti-inflammatory/immunomodulatory: - GlyR-dependent (immune cells: macrophages, Kupffer, neutrophils, T-cells): Hyperpolarization → ↓Ca²⁺ influx → ↓TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, superoxide; ↑IL-10; NF-κB inhibition (partly NRF2-mediated). Effective at 1–3 mM. - Acute experimental (e.g., LPS/endotoxemia, sepsis, IRI models): Rapid (minutes–hours) attenuation of cytokine surge, neutrophil infiltration, organ damage. - Chronic supp. (e.g., 0.1 g/kg/day ×14 days or 5 g/day): ↓pro-inflammatory cytokines/adipokines, improved insulin response; dietary 0.5% in models prevents infiltration. 4. Antioxidant/cytoprotective (glutathione precursor, IRI protection): - GSH synthesis support: Ongoing with availability; supp. counters age/oxidative stress decline. - IRI/endotoxemia protection: Acute IV/oral (pre-/peri-ischemia) inhibits pore formation, ↓ROS/neutrophils; survival benefits in shock models within hours–days. 5. Sleep-promoting: - Lowers core temperature, shortens NREM latency, stabilizes sleep (possibly via NMDA in suprachiasmatic nucleus or GlyR). - Onset: 3 g oral ~30–60 min pre-bed; subjective improvements next day (↓fatigue, ↑alertness/cognition); polysomnography shows latency reduction in first sleep cycle. NREM increase in first ~90 min post-administration in some models. - Duration: Overnight effects; daytime benefits post-single dose. Limited precise onset/duration per action due to reliance on plasma PK (rapid absorption/peak, short half-life) and chronic use in clinical contexts. Brain effects confirmed but BBB penetration may be rate-limiting at low doses. Pharmacokinetics - Half-life (apparent/elimination): Dose-dependent, 26–245 min (0.43–4.08 h); proportional to dose (e.g., low doses shorter, high doses longer due to intracellular accumulation/saturation). From IV/oral studies (10–91 g). - Absorption/Bioavailability: - Oral: Rapid active transport (small intestine); high bioavailability (~60–90% estimates; predicted ~100% in models; "exceptional" in supplement PK). Plasma peak ~30 min (1 g dose), return to baseline ~3 h (low dose). Increases plasma/CSF/brain glycine. - IV: 100% (reference); used in some IRI/TPN contexts. - Tmax: ~0.5–1 h (solution) or longer (tablets); food may delay/increase exposure in some formulations. - Distribution: Wide (including CNS); Vd not well quantified. - Metabolism/Excretion: Hepatic (various enzymes/pathways: GSH, creatine, one-carbon, etc.); renal component. Dosages, Safe Range, Minimum Effective - Typical dietary: ~2–3 g/day. - General supplemental (sleep, cognition, anti-inflam support): 3–5 g/day oral (safe/tolerated); minimum effective for sleep ~3 g pre-bed. - Schizophrenia (adjunct, negative symptoms; with non-clozapine antipsychotics): 0.4–0.8 g/kg/day (~25–60 g/day for average adult, divided 3x; titrate from ~4 g/day). Effects in 6–8 weeks. Minimum effective: Lower doses (e.g., 10–30 g) tried with mixed results; high doses more consistent in responsive patients. Avoid with clozapine (may worsen symptoms). - Safe range: 1 g/day very well-tolerated; up to 6 g/day ×4 weeks possibly safe; higher (up to 90 g studied) tolerated short-term but nausea/GI risk increases. Long-term high-dose safety limited (potential neurotoxicity concerns unconfirmed). LD50 high (grams/kg in animals). - Other: Stroke (acute, limited data); TPN/irrigation (specific formulations). Always under supervision for high doses. Evidence is strongest for sleep (low-dose) and schizophrenia adjunct (high-dose, mixed replication); many other actions are preclinical/promising but not standard therapy. Consult a healthcare provider, especially with medications (e.g., interacts with clozapine) or conditions. High doses require monitoring.

title: Homemade Immunovir
content: Homemade "Immunovir" is a concept based on an attempt to recreate the effects of Inosine pranobex, a compound that was originally marketed under the brand name Immunovir. Inosine pranobex has been used in some countries as an immune-stimulating drug, often for the treatment of viral infections and immune-related conditions, though its effectiveness and availability vary worldwide. Key Components: Inosine and DMAE The core idea of homemade "Immunovir" typically involves combining inosine and DMAE (Dimethylaminoethanol), two components that, while they have some related properties, do not fully replicate the activity of the original drug. 1. Inosine: This is a nucleoside that the body can convert into various substances important for cell function. It has been used as a supplement for athletic performance and brain function, with some immune-enhancing properties. 2. DMAE (Dimethylaminoethanol): DMAE is a compound sometimes used as a nootropic (cognitive enhancer). It is naturally found in small amounts in the human brain and in some foods, and is believed to promote acetylcholine production, benefiting mood and cognitive functions. Its effects on the immune system are, however, indirect and limited. Mechanism of Action of Real Inosine Pranobex Inosine pranobex is an immunomodulator that is thought to work by: Enhancing lymphocyte activity, particularly T-lymphocytes. Increasing the production of cytokines like interferon-gamma and interleukins, which help combat viruses. Potentially increasing antibody production. Inosine pranobex combines inosine with another component, N,N-dimethylamino-2-propanol p-acetamidobenzoate, which isn’t the same as DMAE and plays a specific role in its immune-stimulating properties. Challenges with Homemade "Immunovir" Combining inosine and DMAE does not replicate the mechanism of Inosine pranobex: Limited Immunomodulatory Effects: While inosine may support cellular energy and metabolic processes, it does not by itself provide the same immune cell activation or cytokine production as the original drug. DMAE's Role: DMAE does not have a clear effect on immune function, and its impact on brain health or mood may vary significantly from person to person. Potential Risks Dosage and Side Effects: Dosage can be hard to standardize without professional oversight. Inosine, for example, has been associated with increased uric acid levels, potentially leading to gout or kidney stones if used in high amounts or over long periods. Ineffectiveness: Because inosine and DMAE do not fully mimic the effects of Inosine pranobex, the resulting mixture may not provide the desired immune benefits, and it lacks clinical backing for immune support. Summary Homemade "Immunovir" using inosine and DMAE may not effectively stimulate the immune system and does not fully replicate the properties of Inosine pranobex. If immune support is needed, it’s generally safer and more effective to consult a healthcare provider to discuss clinically validated supplements or medications rather than relying on untested homemade formulations.

title: Hopantenic Acid
content: Here’s a comprehensive, evidence-based summary of every known pharmacological action, pharmacokinetics (including half-life and absorption), and clinical dosing data for hopantenic acid (also known as Pantogam® / Calcium hopantenate / N-pantoyl-GABA) — with values and mechanisms where available. ([PubMed][1]) --- 🌡️ Pharmacological Actions (Mechanisms & Effects) Hopantenic acid is a central nervous system drug with multiple pharmacological activities: 1) Nootropic / Neurocognitive Effects Enhances learning, memory, and attention; used in cognitive impairment and ADHD. ([link.springer.com][2]) Stimulates energy metabolism in neurons (neuro-metabolic). ([РЛС®][3]) 2) GABAergic Modulation Acts primarily through direct interaction with the GABA{B} receptor-channel complex. ([ABC Health Online][4]) May improve GABA metabolism, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission. ([link.springer.com][2]) 3) Anticonvulsant (Antiepileptic) Effect Exhibits anticonvulsant properties; used adjunctively for seizure disorders. ([РЛС®][3]) 4) Anxiolytic / Mild Sedative Reduces anxiety and exerts a mild calming effect. ([PubMed][5]) 5) Neuroprotective / Antihypoxic Increases brain resistance to hypoxia and toxic insults. ([РЛС®][3]) 6) Motor and Behavioral Regulation Reduces motor excitability and can normalize abnormal behaviors. ([ru.wikipedia.org][6]) 7) Astro- and Neurotrophic Actions Stimulates anabolic processes in neurons; supportive of neuroplasticity. ([РЛС®][3]) 8) Other Proposed Effects (less established) Modulation of other neurotransmitter systems: cholinergic, dopaminergic, etc. (suggested from chemoinformatic analyses). ([ResearchGate][7]) Analgesic properties have been reported anecdotally in some sources. ([ru.wikipedia.org][6]) ➡️ Summary of pharmacodynamic profile: Nootropic + anticonvulsant + mild anxiolytic/sedative + neuroprotective + motor-behavioral modulation. ([РЛС®][3]) --- 🧪 Pharmacokinetics Absorption Rapidly absorbed after oral intake; peak plasma concentrations ~1–1.6 hours after dosing. ([PubMed][1]) Distribution Crosses the blood-brain barrier and distributes into brain, liver, kidneys, and other tissues. ([RxEli][8]) Metabolism Not significantly metabolized in humans; largely present in circulation as the parent compound. ([RxEli][8]) In dogs, a minor glucoside metabolite exists (<5% of radioactivity). ([PubMed][9]) Excretion Excreted unchanged over ~48 hours: ~67.5% via urine and ~28-30% via feces. ([RxEli][8]) Half-Life Elimination half-life in humans: approximately 6.7 hours. ([PubMed][1]) Bioavailability Absolute bioavailability values in humans are not well quantified in published clinical literature, but rapid and substantial GI absorption is consistently reported. ([RxEli][8]) --- 📦 Routes of Administration | Route | Notes | | ---------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Oral | Standard clinical route; rapid absorption with CNS penetration. ([RxEli][8]) | | No IV/IM formulations widely used clinically in approved practice. | | --- 💊 Dosage: Clinical Usage Adults Typical daily dose: 1,500–3,000 mg/day orally, divided. ([RxEli][8]) Single dose: 500 mg–1,000 mg. ([RxEli][8]) Capsules: often 300 mg, 2–4 times/day. ([MedixLife.com][10]) Duration: usually 1–4 months, sometimes up to 6 months. ([RxEli][8]) Children Typical daily dose: ~30 mg/kg/day (e.g., ~750–2,000 mg/day) in ADHD studies. ([PubMed][11]) Dosing generally divided into multiple doses, adjusted by weight. ([drugs.ncats.io][12]) Conditions & Dosing Examples (These vary by clinical standard / region rather than strict global evidence) ADHD (children): ~30 mg/kg/day for ~4 months. ([PubMed][11]) Epilepsy adjunct: 500 mg – 3 g/day in divided doses. ([RxEli][8]) Cognitive impairment / anxiety: 600–1,200 mg/day shown effective in some studies. ([PubMed][5]) Safe & Effective Ranges Minimum effective dose: ~250–500 mg per dose (based on tablet formulations and clinical practice). ([RxEli][8]) Typical therapeutic range: 1.5–3 g/day orally. ([RxEli][8]) Upper limit: Usually ~3 g/day in adults (some protocols allow up to 3.5-4 g/day with monitoring). ([RxEli][8]) --- ⚠️ Safety & Tolerability Generally well-tolerated in studied doses up to ~3 g/day. ([PubMed][5]) Rare side effects: rash, nausea, headache, insomnia, dizziness. Safety in pregnancy and severe renal disease: contraindicated/used with caution in many product specs. No strong evidence of addiction or withdrawal at therapeutic doses. ([go.drugbank.com][13]) --- 📌 Mechanistic Summary | Mechanism | Evidence | | ----------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | GABA-B receptor modulation | Primary accepted action. ([РЛС®][3]) | | Increased neuronal resistance to hypoxia | Supported in clinical sources. ([РЛС®][3]) | | Improved memory/cognition | Observed in clinical practice/studies. ([link.springer.com][2]) | | Anxiolytic effect | Reported, especially with racemic formulation. ([PubMed][5]) | | Anticonvulsant effect | Recognized in product literature. ([РЛС®][3]) | | Other receptor systems (opioid/dopamine)? | Suggested in chemoinformatic analyses (less direct clinical evidence). ([ResearchGate][7]) | --- 📊 Summary Table (Key Values) | Parameter | Value / Range | | ------------------- | ----------------------------------------------- | | Tmax (oral) | ~1.0–1.6 h ([PubMed][1]) | | Half-Life (t½) | ~6.7 h ([PubMed][1]) | | Excretion | ~67.5% urine, ~28–30% feces ([RxEli][8]) | | Bioavailability | Rapid; exact % not well quantified ([RxEli][8]) | | Adult dose | ~1,500–3,000 mg/day orally ([RxEli][8]) | | Child dose | ~30 mg/kg/day (ADHD studies) ([PubMed][11]) | --- If you want, I can provide structured citations linked to the primary studies or product monographs for each claim or a PDF-style summary of all mechanisms and kinetics. [1]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20919560/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "[Pharmacokinetics of hopantenic acid upon peroral administration] - PubMed" [2]: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1134/S1819712423020198?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Cognitive Impairment and Nootropic Drugs: Mechanism of ..." [3]: https://www.rlsnet.ru/drugs/gopantenovaya-kislota-lekt-81320?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Гопантеновая кислота-ЛекТ" [4]: https://abchealthonline.com/6589603-hopantenic-acid-instructions-for-use-price-reviews-analogues?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Hopantenic Acid - Instructions For Use, Price, Reviews, Analogues | Medicines" [5]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26978493/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "[Pantogam activ (D-, L-hopantenic acid) in the treatment of cognitive and anxiety disorders in patients with arterial hypertension] - PubMed" [6]: https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%8F%D0%BA%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B0?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Гопантеновая кислота" [7]: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/304207788Neurotropicanti-inflammatoryandantitumorpropertiesofhopantenicacidAchemoinformaticanalysisofitsmolecule?utmsource=chatgpt.com "A chemoinformatic analysis of its molecule | Request PDF" [8]: https://rxeli.com/product/pantocalcin-hopantenic-acid-250-mg-50-tablets/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "ᐈ Buy Pantocalcin® (Hopantenic Acid) 250 mg, 50 tablets Online • RxEli" [9]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2877836/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Hopantenic acid beta-glucoside as a new urinary metabolite of calcium hopantenate in dogs - PubMed" [10]: https://www.medixlife.com/pantogam-active-instructions/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Pantogam® Active Dosage, Warnings, Drug Interactions, Side Effects" [11]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28638029/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "[Pharmacotherapy of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in children: the results of a multicenter double-blind placebo-controlled study of hopantenic acid] - PubMed" [12]: https://drugs.ncats.io/substance/H473MVB16U?utmsource=chatgpt.com "HOPANTENIC ACID" [13]: https://go.drugbank.com/drugs/DB14044?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Hopantenic acid: Uses, Interactions, Mechanism of Action"

title: Hyaluronidase
content: Pharmacological Actions of Hyaluronidase (LYDASE) Hyaluronidase is an enzyme that primarily catalyzes the hydrolysis of hyaluronic acid (HA), a glycosaminoglycan in the extracellular matrix of connective tissues. LYDASE is a specific formulation of hyaluronidase derived from bovine (cattle) testes, typically available in strengths like 64 IU/mL or 1280 IU per ampoule. It acts as a "spreading factor" by depolymerizing HA, reducing its viscosity, and increasing tissue permeability. This facilitates fluid movement, drug dispersion, and resolution of tissue abnormalities. The enzyme cleaves β-1,4 glycosidic bonds between glucosamine and glucuronic acid in HA, leading to temporary microchannels in tissues. Below is a comprehensive list of pharmacological actions, based on available data from clinical and pharmacological sources. For each action, I've included time-related values (e.g., onset, duration, and how it influences the action). Onset is generally immediate upon subcutaneous (SC) injection, with peak effects within minutes to hours. Duration of action is 24-48 hours due to the enzyme's high potency, despite a short half-life (2-3 minutes in plasma; <30 minutes in subcutaneous tissue). These times can vary by dose, route, and patient factors. Influences are described qualitatively, with quantitative impacts where data exists (e.g., extent of permeability increase or HA degradation). | Pharmacological Action | Description and Influence | Time Values | |------------------------|---------------------------|-------------| | Depolymerization of Hyaluronic Acid | Breaks down HA into monosaccharides (glucosamine and glucuronic acid), reducing extracellular matrix viscosity by up to 50-90% temporarily. This creates microchannels, allowing better fluid flow and tissue remodeling. Influences: Reduces tissue resistance, aiding in scar softening and edema resolution. | Onset: Immediate (within 1-2 minutes of injection). Peak: 10-30 minutes. Duration: 24-48 hours (HA half-life is 15-20 hours naturally; enzyme extends degradation). Full tissue restoration: 48 hours. | | Increase in Tissue Permeability | Enhances permeability of connective tissues and blood vessels by hydrolyzing acid mucopolysaccharides. Influences: Improves diffusion of fluids/drugs by 2-5 times the rate without hyaluronidase, reducing interstitial pressure and facilitating absorption. | Onset: Immediate. Peak: 5-15 minutes. Duration: 24-48 hours. Rate of diffusion proportional to dose (e.g., 150 IU increases spread by 3-4x in animal models). | | Facilitation of Drug/Fluid Absorption and Dispersion | Acts as an adjuvant to spread injected substances (e.g., local anesthetics, contrast agents). Influences: Increases bioavailability of co-administered drugs by 20-50%, hastens onset of analgesia (e.g., reduces swelling and enhances anesthetic spread). | Onset: Immediate. Peak: 10-20 minutes. Duration: 24-48 hours. For example, with local anesthetics, onset hastened by 5-10 minutes, but systemic absorption may shorten duration by 20-30%. | | Reduction of Tissue Swelling (Edema) | Decreases viscosity of interstitial fluids, promoting resorption of exudates/transudates. Influences: Reduces edema volume by 30-60% in hypodermoclysis or extravasation cases. | Onset: 5-15 minutes. Peak: 30-60 minutes. Duration: Up to 48 hours. Reported in <0.1% of cases as a side effect, but therapeutic in edema management. | | Scar Softening and Flattening | Softens hypertrophic/keloid scars by breaking down HA in scar tissue. Influences: Reduces scar hardness by 20-40%, improves elasticity, and prevents contracture formation. Specific to LYDASE: Used for burn scars, ulcers, and post-surgical adhesions. | Onset: 24-48 hours per injection. Peak: After 10-20 injections (cumulative). Duration: Effects last weeks to months with repeated dosing; single dose: 24-48 hours. | | Improvement in Joint Mobility | Increases range of motion in stiff joints (e.g., contractures, Dupuytren's). Influences: Enhances synovial fluid movement, reducing stiffness by 15-30% in affected joints. | Onset: 1-2 hours. Peak: 24 hours. Duration: 24-48 hours per dose; repeated for chronic conditions. | | Reversal of HA-Based Fillers | Degrades cosmetic HA fillers (off-label). Influences: Dissolves fillers by 50-90% depending on dose; reverses vascular occlusion or overfilling. | Onset: Immediate (softening in minutes). Peak: 24-48 hours. Duration: Effects continue up to 48 hours; full reversal may require multiple doses. | | Promotion of Hematoma/Extravasation Resolution | Aids resorption of leaked drugs/fluids (e.g., chemotherapy extravasation). Influences: Speeds clearance by 2-3x, reducing tissue damage. | Onset: 15-30 minutes. Peak: 1-2 hours. Duration: 24-48 hours. | These actions are primarily local, with minimal systemic effects due to rapid inactivation in blood. LYDASE-specific influences include targeted use for connective tissue disorders, with effects lasting up to 48 hours SC. Half-Life - Plasma half-life: 2-3 minutes (rapid deactivation by blood components). - Subcutaneous tissue half-life: <30 minutes. - Overall duration of action: 24-48 hours (due to high enzymatic potency and temporary HA degradation; native HA regenerates in 15-20 hours). Bioavailabilities by Route Hyaluronidase is a protein enzyme, so bioavailability varies by administration route.
