title: Peptide Complex A 12
content: Pharmacological Actions of Peptide Complex A-12 (Chitomur) Peptide Complex A-12, commercially known as Chitomur, is a natural peptide bioregulator derived from the bladder tissue of young animals. It is classified as a food supplement and an additional source of peptides, rather than a pharmaceutical drug. Its primary pharmacological actions are focused on supporting and regulating bladder function. Based on available product information and general knowledge of similar peptide bioregulators (e.g., Khavinson peptides), the key actions include: - Regulation of cellular metabolism in bladder wall cells: Normalizes metabolic processes in the urinary bladder wall, promoting cellular health and repair. This action helps restore tissue structure and function, particularly in cases of decreased kidney activity or dystrophic changes in the genitourinary system. Influence: Improves overall bladder resilience against environmental stressors, poor diet, and age-related decline. - Stimulation of muscle tone in the detrusor and sphincter: Enhances the contractile function of the bladder's detrusor muscle (responsible for bladder emptying) and sphincter (responsible for continence). Influence: Reduces symptoms of urinary incontinence and improves control over urination, especially in conditions like pelvic organ prolapse or neurogenic bladder dysfunction. - Regulatory effect on cell reproduction and specialization (autocrine level): Acts at the cellular level to influence autocrine signaling, supporting cell proliferation, differentiation, and repair in bladder tissues. Influence: Aids in tissue restoration and prevents further degradation in chronic conditions, potentially reducing inflammation and improving bladder flexibility. - Support for urinary tract integrity and health: Promotes balanced tissue function within the bladder walls, acting as an adjunct in managing urinary disorders. Influence: Alleviates symptoms associated with chronic inflammation or hormonal changes, such as those in menopause or prostate-related issues. These actions are selective to bladder tissues, with no broad systemic effects reported beyond genitourinary support. They are based on the peptide's bioregulatory properties, which are claimed to normalize function without overriding natural processes. No specific quantitative "values for each time" (e.g., onset of action, peak effect, or duration) are available in product literature or related sources, as Chitomur is not a regulated drug with formal pharmacokinetic studies. However, general peptide bioregulators like this are described as having gradual effects over weeks to months with consistent use, rather than immediate pharmacological impacts. For context, similar short peptides (di-, tri-, or tetrapeptides) in this class may begin influencing cellular metabolism within days, with full benefits observed after 1-3 months of administration. Half-Life No specific half-life data is available for Peptide Complex A-12 (Chitomur). As a short peptide complex (typically consisting of low-molecular-weight peptides like di-, tri-, or tetrapeptides from organ extracts), it likely has a very short plasma half-life, on the order of minutes to hours, due to rapid enzymatic degradation and renal clearance. General literature on therapeutic peptides indicates half-lives of 2-8 hours for many unmodified peptides, but ultra-short bioregulators like those in Khavinson's line may be even shorter (e.g., <30 minutes) without modifications for extension. This short half-life necessitates daily dosing to maintain effects. Bioavailabilities (Including Oral Route) No specific bioavailability data is provided for Peptide Complex A-12 (Chitomur). It is administered orally as capsules, and product claims suggest it is absorbed sufficiently to exert effects, likely via sublingual or gastrointestinal routes (though not explicitly stated). General knowledge of unmodified peptides indicates: - Oral bioavailability: Typically low, <1-2% for most peptides due to enzymatic degradation in the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., by proteases like pepsin and trypsin), poor membrane permeability, and first-pass metabolism. For short peptide bioregulators like Chitomur, bioavailability may be slightly higher (estimated 0.1-5%) if they are designed for mucosal absorption or partial resistance to digestion, but no exact values are substantiated. - Other routes: Not applicable, as Chitomur is formulated for oral use only in capsule form. Sublingual versions (e.g., Chitomur Lingual) may offer higher bioavailability (comparable to subcutaneous injection, per general peptide catalogs), potentially 10-20%, due to direct mucosal absorption bypassing the liver. Intravenous administration of similar peptides achieves 100% bioavailability but is not used for this product. - Factors influencing bioavailability: Chitomur's hydrophilic nature and molecular weight (>500 Da for peptide complexes) limit passive absorption. No enhancements (e.g., permeation enhancers or PEGylation) are mentioned, so values remain low. Dosages (Including Safe Range and Minimum Effective) Chitomur is available in capsules containing approximately 10-20 mg of Peptide Complex A-12 per capsule (varies by manufacturer; e.g., 10 mg in some formulations, up to 20 mg in others, with the complex including amino acids like lysine, leucine, isoleucine, valine, glutamic acid, aspartic acid, serine, and alanine). - Recommended dosage: Adults take 1-2 capsules, 1-2 times per day before meals. This equates to 10-80 mg of the peptide complex daily. - Duration: 1-3 months per course, with repetition every 3-6 months for maintenance. - Minimum effective dosage: Likely 1 capsule (10-20 mg) once daily, based on product recommendations for milder support. Effects may be subtle at this level, with literature suggesting gradual benefits over time. - Safe range: 1-4 capsules per day (10-80 mg peptide complex), as no toxicity is reported. As a food supplement, it is considered safe within this range for adults without contraindications. No upper toxic limit is specified, but exceeding 4 capsules/day is not recommended without professional advice. - Adjustments: Intensive courses may use 2 capsules twice daily (40-80 mg) for severe conditions like chronic cystitis or incontinence. For maintenance, reduce to 1 capsule daily. - Contraindications: Individual intolerance, pregnancy, lactation. No reported drug interactions or overdose risks. These details are derived from product catalogs and descriptions for Chitomur (Peptide Complex A-12). As a supplement, it lacks rigorous clinical pharmacokinetic studies, so values are estimates based on general peptide pharmacology. For personalized use, consult a healthcare provider.

title: Peptide Complex A 13
content: The term “Peptide complex A-13” is not a well-defined pharmacological drug in the scientific or medical literature. What is commonly referred to in peer-reviewed pharmacology are endogenous peptides with 13 amino acids, notably: 1. Apelin-13 (also called Pyr¹-apelin-13) — a biologically active peptide fragment of the apelin family that activates the APJ (apelin) G-protein-coupled receptor and has cardiovascular, metabolic, and neuroprotective actions. ([Wikipedia][1]) 2. Dynorphin A¹-13 — the 13-amino-acid form of the opioid peptide dynorphin A, active at κ-opioid receptors (KOR) with opioid-related pharmacology. ([Wikipedia][2]) Below is the most complete summary available of pharmacological actions, pharmacokinetics (half-life and bioavailability), and dosing information for each — with citations. Note: formal clinical dosing and bioavailability data for these peptides as drugs do not exist in humans outside research settings; most information is from animal or in-vitro studies. --- 1) Apelin-13 (Pyr¹-apelin-13) Pharmacological Actions Receptor / Mechanism Endogenous ligand for the APJ receptor (a Gαi-coupled GPCR). ([guidetopharmacology.org][3]) Activation decreases cAMP, recruits β-arrestin, and triggers MAPK/ERK and Akt signaling. ([Frontiers][4]) Major Actions Cardiovascular Vasodilation: decreases peripheral resistance via endothelium-dependent NO release. ([Wikipedia][1]) Positive inotropy: increases cardiac contractility in isolated heart models. ([MDPI][5]) Blood pressure lowering (hypotensive) in rodents. ([OUP Academic][6]) Metabolic & Other Effects Modulates glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity (preclinical). ([Frontiers][7]) Anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects in CNS disease models, regulates apoptosis and autophagy. ([ScienceDirect][8]) Temporal Pharmacodynamics Onset of cardiovascular effects in rodents tends to occur within minutes of intravenous infusion, with the peak and duration limited by rapid degradation. ([benchchem.com][9]) Pharmacokinetics Half-Life Very short systemic half-life when administered exogenously: <3 minutes in rat plasma after intravenous administration. ([benchchem.com][9]) Reported ~7–14 minutes in isolated plasma assays depending on species and assay conditions. ([benchchem.com][9]) Bioavailability Not orally bioavailable in native form due to proteolytic degradation and first-pass metabolism (typical of peptides). ([benchchem.com][9]) Parenteral (IV/SC) bioavailability is much higher than any oral uptake but varies with formulation; no formal human bioavailability reported. Some formulations (PEGylated/liposomal) in preclinical models dramatically increase systemic exposure compared with native peptide. ([benchchem.com][10]) Dosing (Research Use Only) There are no approved therapeutic doses of apelin-13 for humans. In animal research, doses are typically: Cardiovascular studies in rodents: ~0.1–1.0 µg/kg IV produces hemodynamic effects. ([MDPI][5]) Some chronic models use ~10–300 nmol/kg per day via IP or SC. ([MDPI][5]) Minimum Effective Dose is model-dependent and not standardized in humans. Safety / Notes Not approved as a drug; dosing should only be interpreted in a research context. Rapid degradation by ACE2 and other peptidases limits duration of action. ([Frontiers][4]) --- 2) Dynorphin A¹-13 > Caveat: Dynorphin A is a natural opioid neuropeptide with wide effects but no approved clinical peptide drug form. Dynorphin-based agents are mainly research tools. Pharmacological Actions Receptor / Mechanism Full or partial agonist at κ-opioid receptors (KOR), also interacts with μ and δ receptors in some settings. ([Wikipedia][11]) Major Effects Analgesia / Pain modulation: classic opioid mechanisms in rodents and some early human research. ([Wikipedia][2]) Neuroendocrine effects: modulates prolactin secretion in small human studies. ([PubMed][12]) Possible regulation of mood and stress circuits via KOR modulation. ([Wikipedia][11]) Temporal Action Rapid onset with direct central or peripheral administration; duration depends on route and metabolism (typically short). Human detailed profiles not established. Pharmacokinetics Half-Life Very short in plasma: <1 minute in human plasma ex-vivo due to rapid proteolysis. ([PubMed][13]) More stable in cerebrospinal fluid in vitro (~2.5 h), but this does not reflect systemic kinetics. ([PubMed][14]) Bioavailability No established oral bioavailability — likely negligible in humans due to peptidase degradation. Experimental administration in humans has been via infusion or injection in research; no formal bioavailability values published. Dosing (Research) Early human research used opioid-experienced volunteers with loads sufficient to affect withdrawal or hormone levels (specific doses varying by study). ([PubMed][15]) No approved clinical or safe dosing range in humans. --- General Pharmacological Patterns of Peptide Drugs Because both apelin-13 and dynorphin A¹-13 are peptides: Oral bioavailability is essentially zero for native peptides (rapid GI degradation). ([benchchem.com][9]) Parenteral routes (IV, SC) are required for systemic exposure. ([benchchem.com][9]) Unmodified peptides have very short half-lives in circulation (minutes), unless chemically modified. ([benchchem.com][9]) Modifications (PEGylation, lipidation) can extend half-life to hours in preclinical models. ([benchchem.com][10]) --- Summary Table (Apelin-13 vs Dynorphin A¹-13) | Property | Apelin-13 | Dynorphin A¹-13 | | ---------------------- | ----------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------- | | Primary Receptor | APJ (GPCR) | κ-opioid (KOR), others | | Key Actions | Vasodilation, inotropy, metabolic effects | Opioid analgesia, neuroendocrine modulation | | Half-Life (unmodified) | ~<3–<15 min in rodents | <1 min plasma | | Oral Bioavailability | Negligible | Negligible | | Known Human Dosing | Research use only | Research use only | | Routes Used | IV/SC in studies | IV/central/experimental | --- Important Safety & Clinical Context There are no approved therapeutic peptide drugs called “A-13”. All pharmacological and dosing data above are from preclinical or early human research settings; they are not medical recommendations. Use of peptides outside controlled research or approved clinical trials can be unsafe. --- If what you meant by “peptide complex A-13” refers to a specific proprietary formulation, drug candidate, or patented peptide construct, let me know any additional identifiers (e.g., a patent number or full peptide sequence). I can then look up precise pharmacological and clinical data for that specific molecule. title: Peptide Complex A 16
content: Here’s a clear, accurate, and evidence-based summary of what Libidon is and what is (and is not) known about its pharmacology, dosing, kinetics, safety, etc. --- ❗ What Libidon Actually Is Libidon is not a conventional pharmaceutical drug with defined pharmacological actions, metabolism, or standardized clinical pharmacokinetics. It is marketed in many countries as a dietary supplement / peptide bioregulator primarily aimed at men’s reproductive health and prostate support. ([Peptide store, iPept.com][1]) The active components are peptide complexes (labeled A-16 or A-21 depending on product/region) — short chains of amino acids derived from animal tissues — that are claimed to target prostate cells. ([Peptide store, iPept.com][1]) Because it is a supplement, not an approved drug, there are no standard pharmacological actions, no regulatory pharmacokinetic studies, no established half-life, no proven bioavailability values, and no official LD₅₀ data in humans or animals. --- 🧠 Reported/Claimed Actions According to product descriptions and limited manufacturer materials: 🔹 Proposed (Not Clinically Proven) Effects Libidon’s peptide complexes are claimed to: Support prostate gland metabolic function Assist in prostate cell normalization Improve reproductive system function Support libido and ejaculate quality Help with erectile function Support recovery/maintenance in chronic prostatitis and BPH (BPH = benign prostatic hyperplasia) ([Peptide store, iPept.com][1]) ⚠️ Keep in mind: These actions are not recognized drug mechanisms validated by regulatory authorities. They are marketing descriptions based on “bioregulator” peptide concepts used in some alternative medicine traditions. --- 📊 Pharmacokinetics (What We Don’t Know) Because Libidon is a supplement: ❌ No reliably measured values exist for: Absorption/bioavailability (including oral vs sublingual) Onset of effect times Plasma half-life Metabolism Distribution Clearance/elimination Standard pharmacokinetic profiling (like what’s done for approved drugs) has not been published in peer-reviewed literature for this product or its proprietary peptides. Therefore, there are no verified numbers for: Time to peak concentration (Tmax) Half-life (t½) Absolute or relative bioavailability This kind of data simply does not exist in recognized scientific databases for Libidon. --- 💊 Dosing Information (Marketed Use) The available product formulations include: 1. Capsule Form Common recommendation: 1–2 capsules 1–2 times daily with meals Each daily dose often delivers about 20–40 mg of peptide complex A-16 or A-21 Typical course: 1 month, with optional repeats after 1–2 months (source product info) ([Peptide store, iPept.com][1]) 2. Sublingual (Drops / Lingual) Form Suggested: ~10 drops under the tongue, twice daily Daily exposure ~10 mg peptide Course: ~1 month ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][2]) ⚠️ These are manufacturer recommendations for a food supplement — not clinically validated therapeutic doses. --- 🩺 Safety, Side Effects & Toxicology ✅ What Is Generally Claimed Manufacturers/labels often state that Libidon: Has no side effects Can be used with other male health treatments Is “well tolerated” ([Peptidi][3]) ❌ Known Limitations There are no official safety studies (no large clinical trials in humans, no FDA EMA pharmacovigilance, etc.) that provide: LD₅₀ (median lethal dose) Therapeutic Index Systemic toxicology Clinical adverse event rates Because there’s no standardized pharmacology or controlled trials, risks cannot be quantified. Without LD₅₀ data, we cannot give doses that “become dangerous.” ⚠️ Supplements can still interact with medications (e.g., blood thinners, hormone therapies) and may cause allergic or idiosyncratic reactions even if marketed as “natural.” --- ⚠️ Important Notes Before Use Dietary supplements are not regulated like drugs in most countries. Their claimed effects are often not clinically confirmed. Terms like “clinical studies” on some vendor sites are usually internal or small, non-peer-reviewed and don’t meet regulatory evidence standards. If you are taking prescription drugs or have medical conditions, consult a physician before using any supplement. --- 📌 Summary | Category | Known / Established | | -------------------------- | --------------------------------------------- | | Pharmacological mechanisms | Claimed, not scientifically proven | | Half-life | No data available | | Bioavailability | No validated measurements | | Dosing | Manufacturer recommendations (supplement) | | LD₅₀ / safety thresholds | Not established | | Regulatory drug status | Not approved as a pharmaceutical | --- If you want, I can help look up scientific studies on bioregulatory peptides like A-16/A-21 or explain how supplements differ from licensed medications in terms of evidence and regulation. title: Peptide Complex A 17
content: Here’s what can be reliably gathered about Glandokort — including what it is, what its claimed pharmacological actions are, and what established pharmacokinetic / safety data exist — based on currently available scientific and supplier information from published sources. Important caveat: Glandokort is not a standard pharmaceutical drug with well-characterized pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics, toxicity studies, or regulated dosage and safety data. Most details come from product descriptions or small clinical reports in Russia and supplement sellers, not from modern peer-reviewed drug research. ([Peptide store, iPept.com][1]) --- 🧬 What Glandokort Is Glandokort is marketed as a peptide bioregulator supplement containing a complex of peptides called A-17, derived from adrenal glands of young animals. It is promoted to support adrenal gland function and endocrine balance and is classified as a dietary supplement/bioregulator, not a verified pharmaceutical. ([Peptide store, iPept.com][1]) Claimed Pharmacological Actions The advertised mechanisms (mostly from manufacturer/clinical reports) include: Selective effect on adrenal gland cells, supporting their metabolism and function. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][2]) Normalization of hormone production — cortisol, adrenaline, noradrenaline — to help stress response and metabolism. ([uaepeptidesresearch.com][3]) Restoration of functional activity of the endocrine system after stress, nutritional or environmental disruption. ([antiaging-systems.com][4]) Tissue-specific gene expression modulation via short peptides—claimed in older Russian research on peptide bioregulators in general (not specific A-17 data). ([peptides1.ru][5]) Important: These actions are claimed based on limited clinical reports and theoretical bioregulator mechanisms — not established by modern pharmacology standards. --- ⏱ Pharmacokinetics — What We Do Not Know For conventional drugs, pharmacokinetics include absorption, bioavailability, distribution, metabolism, and excretion. For Glandokort: Bioavailability (oral): No published human data exist because Glandokort is not an approved drug with formal PK studies. Manufacturers claim that sublingual (lingual) forms have faster and higher absorption because they enter circulation via the oral mucosa without first-pass metabolism. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][2]) However, there are no validated bioavailability percentages available. Half-life: No reported half-life data for A-17 peptides in the bloodstream are available in the literature. Time-to-onset: Claims by sellers suggest sublingual administration is faster than capsules, but no human trial data provide reliable onset times. Summary: There’s no peer-reviewed pharmacokinetic data (half-life, Tmax, Cmax, AUC) for Glandokort/A-17 peptides available. --- 💊 Dosage Information – Supplement Marketplace Since Glandokort is marketed as a supplement, standard scientific dose-finding and toxicology (like ED50 or LD50) do not exist in regulatory literature. What follows are recommended product dosages from manufacturer/seller descriptions: Capsule Form (oral): Typical: 1–2 capsules once or twice daily with meals. ([Peptide store, iPept.com][6]) Dosage per capsule: ~10 mg A-17 peptides (so 20 mg per day with 2 capsules). ([Peptide store, iPept.com][6]) Course duration: 30 days, repeat after 1-2 months if needed. ([Peptide store, iPept.com][6]) Lingual (sublingual) Form: Typical: 10 drops under tongue twice daily (~10 mg active total per day). ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][2]) Some sources suggest 5–6 drops 3–4 times daily for up to 1 month. ([Bio Peptides][7]) These are supplement manufacturer recommendations, not evidence-based clinical regimens. --- ⚠️ Safety, Toxicity, LD50, and Adverse Risk LD50 / Toxicity There are no LD50 values, NOAEL, or formal toxicity studies for Glandokort/A-17 peptides in accessible scientific literature. This is typical for supplements not regulated as drugs. Some supplier materials and small clinical reports claim no identified side effects during routine use, but these are not robust toxicity studies. ([antiaging-systems.com][4]) Side Effects / Risks No well-documented adverse events or toxicity profiles exist. Contraindications noted by sellers: pregnancy, breastfeeding, individual intolerance. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][2]) As with any biologically active supplement, allergic reactions or unknown interactions with medications are theoretically possible. "Too Dangerous" Threshold Because there are no formal controlled toxicology studies, there is no established margin between dose and toxicity, and no toxic dose threshold. --- ❗ Summary Table | Category | Known / Available | Unknown / Not Established | | ------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------- | | Mechanism claims | Adrenal support, hormone balance (claimed) | Receptor binding profiles, gene targets validated | | Half-life | — | ✓ | | Bioavailability | Sublingual claimed higher | Exact % for oral/sublingual | | Safe doses | Manufacturer suggestions | Therapeutic window in humans | | LD50 / toxicity | — | ✓ | | Clinical efficacy in rigorous trials | Claim from older Russian studies | Modern RCT evidence | --- ⚠️ Scientific and Regulatory Context Peptide bioregulators like Glandokort were developed in Russian research by Vladimir Khavinson and colleagues; they are sometimes described in older Russian clinical literature but are not standard pharmaceuticals approved with full pharmacologic characterization in Western medicine. ([PubMed][8]) Thus, while supplement sellers and small clinical manuals claim beneficial actions, there is no established pharmacokinetic or toxicology data comparable to that of approved drugs. --- 📌 Final Notes If you are considering using Glandokort or related peptides: Consult a qualified healthcare provider — especially if you are on other medications, pregnant, breastfeeding, or have health conditions. Be cautious about interpreting supplement claims as clinical evidence. Understand that broad safety margins or toxicology data do not exist in the scientific literature for this product. --- If you want, I can help you compare Glandokort with pharmaceutical adrenal support drugs (like hydrocortisone) and outline their known pharmacology too. title: Peptide Complex A 3
content: Here is a scientifically grounded summary of what’s actually known about the pharmacology, actions, kinetics, dosing, and bioavailability of “peptide complex A-3” (which largely refers in the research literature to the A3-APO antimicrobial peptide) — NOT a general marketing name or supplement (which often has no reliable data) — based on peer-reviewed sources: --- 🧬 What Peptide “A3” / A3-APO Actually Is Peptide A3-APO is a synthetic antimicrobial peptide (proline-rich dimeric peptide) designed to act as an antibiotic-type agent against bacteria, especially multidrug-resistant strains. It is not a general nutraceutical or human-use peptide found in medicine today; most data are from preclinical (animal/in vitro) studies. ([PubMed][1]) Core documented pharmacological actions include: ▶️ 1) Antibacterial Activity Broad-spectrum bactericidal effect against Gram-negative and Gram-positive pathogens in cell culture. ([PubMed][1]) Works by disrupting bacterial cell membranes and inhibiting bacterial protein folding via binding to the bacterial DnaK heat-shock protein — a dual mode of action. ([PubMed][2]) ▶️ 2) Synergistic Action with Antibiotics A3-APO can significantly lower MICs (minimum inhibitory concentrations) of conventional antibiotics when used in combination. ([mdpi.com][3]) ▶️ 3) Effect in Animal Models In mouse bacteremia/infection models, intramuscular or intravenous A3-APO reduced bacterial counts and increased survival vs untreated controls. ([PubMed][4]) ▶️ 4) Selectivity & Mammalian Cell Toxicity Shows selective bacterial action at antimicrobial concentrations. Mammalian cytotoxicity (cell proliferation inhibition) occurs at much higher micromolar levels compared to antimicrobial MICs. ([mdpi.com][3]) ※ There is no credible evidence that this peptide has endocrine, metabolic, growth-promoting, anti-inflammatory, anti-aging, or cartilage-repair actions in humans. --- 📊 Pharmacokinetics (What We Know and What We Don’t) 🔹 Half-Life There are no published human or full animal PK studies providing precise half-life (T½) values for A3-APO. General peptide pharmacokinetics context Most small peptides like A3-APO (~1 kDa range) are rapidly cleared via proteolysis and renal filtration: typical peptide half-lives are often minutes to a few hours without stabilization. ([deltapeptides.com][5]) Thus, any specific half-life must be measured experimentally — but no such published values for A3-APO exist. 🔹 Bioavailability There is no data on A3-APO oral bioavailability. In general for peptides: Oral bioavailability of peptides is extremely low unless specially formulated (usually <5%). ([sciencedirect.com][6]) Parenteral routes (IV, IM, SC) bypass digestion and yield much higher systemic exposure. ([deltapeptides.com][5]) Thus: Oral bioavailability: not established, likely negligible Intravenous / intramuscular: biologically active in animal models, so functional systemic availability is confirmed via parenteral dosing. 🔹 Time to Peak / Distribution No controlled pharmacokinetic time-course (e.g., Tmax, Cmax, AUC) data in animals or humans is published for A3-APO. --- 💉 Dosing & Safety Data (Preclinical) 📍 Animal Infectious Disease Models From published mouse studies of A3-APO: Effective IM doses: 5–10 mg/kg given twice or thrice reduced bacterial burden and improved survival. ([PubMed][4]) IV dose example: 2.5 mg/kg also effective. ([PubMed][4]) No toxic effects reported at 60 mg/kg IM in mice as compared to lower toxic thresholds after IV/IP routes. ([PubMed][4]) ⚠️ Translating animal doses to human contexts requires careful allometric scaling and clinical safety data — which do not exist for A3-APO. 📍 MIC (In Vitro Antimicrobial Potency) For reference, lab MICs for bacterial inhibition in culture: MIC range: 2.5–15 µM for sensitive/resistant strains. ([mdpi.com][3]) 📍 Cytotoxicity Window IC50 for mammalian cell proliferation (~HEK, Vero cells): ~26–33 µM, significantly above MICs. ([mdpi.com][3]) --- ⚠️ Important Limitations & Gaps (Critical to Understand) 🔹 No human clinical data exists — no approved human dose, no human bioavailability or half-life data, no safety profile in humans. 🔹 Published work is preclinical (in vitro + animal) only. 🔹 Terms like “peptide complex A-3” on commercial supplement sites often do not refer to this research peptide and may be misleading. --- 📌 Summary: Known / Unknown | Parameter | Known | Unknown | | ---------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------- | ------- | | Mechanism of antimicrobial action | Yes (dual bacterial membrane + DnaK interference) ([PubMed][2]) | N/A | | In vitro MIC values | 2.5–15 µM ([mdpi.com][3]) | — | | Animal parenteral efficacy (mg/kg) | Yes (~2.5–10 mg/kg) ([PubMed][4]) | — | | Mammalian cytotoxicity range | Yes (IC50 ~26–33 µM) ([mdpi.com][3]) | — | | Half-life in animals or humans | Unknown | — | | Oral bioavailability | Unknown but likely negligible | — | | Human dosing & safety | None | — | --- 🧠 Final Notes If you meant a different peptide (e.g., marketed “A-3” supplement): clarify the exact sequence or intended compound, because there is no authoritative pharmacological dataset corresponding to generic product names like “peptide complex A-3” in humans. For clinical pharmacology information, one must look to published data on defined peptide drugs (e.g., approved AMPs or peptide therapeutics), as the research A3-APO peptide has not advanced to human dosing studies. --- If you want, I can help you interpret a specific peptide sequence or research compound and find all published pharmacokinetic and dosing data for that exact molecule. title: Peptide Complex A 4
content: Here’s a clear, fact-based summary of what is known about Sigumir — based on the available scientific and product information — and what is not documented in credible pharmacology sources. ⚠️ Important Overall Note Sigumir is not a registered pharmaceutical drug in major regulatory systems (FDA, EMA, etc.). The products marketed as Sigumir are dietary supplements/bioregulators based on cartilage-derived peptide complexes, not approved medicines with standardized pharmacokinetics or toxicity data. That means: There is no verified clinical pharmacology profile (e.g., half-life, receptor binding, systemic bioavailability) published in peer-reviewed journals. There are no established LD50 values, therapeutic index, or safety thresholds from controlled toxicology studies in humans. Dosage recommendations come from product labeling and small clinical studies in Russia, not mainstream pharmacological literature. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) --- 🧬 What Sigumir Is Sigumir (a peptide bioregulator) is described as: A complex of low–molecular-weight peptides (often “peptide complex A-4”) extracted from cartilage and bone tissue of young animals. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) Intended to support cartilage metabolism and joint health and to promote regenerative processes in cartilage and bone cells. ([Bioregulator Peptides][2]) Marketed as a nutritional supplement or bioregulator, not a pharmaceutical drug. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][3]) Proposed Mechanisms (from product descriptions) Reported effects are based on limited clinical and experimental descriptions, not established pharmacodynamics: Stimulates chondrocyte function and cartilage repair (metabolic support). ([Bioregulator Peptides][2]) Reduces joint inflammation and stiffness (claimed). ([Bioregulator Peptides][2]) Supports lubrication and flexibility of joints (claimed). ([Bioregulator Peptides][2]) Regulation of intracellular metabolic processes in cartilage and bone cells (claimed). ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) > Important: These mechanisms are proposed in marketing materials and small clinical observations; they are not established in mainstream pharmacology texts. --- 📈 Pharmacological Action Summary | Action / Effect | Evidence Source | Notes | | --------------------------------------- | --------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Cartilage trophism / metabolism support | Supplement literature | Not confirmed by robust clinical trials. ([Anti Aging Peptides][4]) | | Joint flexibility improvement | Supplement literature | Described in product info. ([Bioregulator Peptides][2]) | | Anti-inflammatory effects | Supplement literature | Claimed but not quantified in rigorous studies. ([Bioregulator Peptides][2]) | | Bone tissue support | Supplement literature | Marketing claims exist. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) | --- 🧪 Pharmacokinetics & Bioavailability There are no reliable published values for: Absorption kinetics (e.g., plasma levels after oral dosing) Half-life (t½) Volume of distribution Clearance or metabolic pathways Bioavailability (oral or sublingual) Manufacturers claim that: Sublingual use may increase bioavailability and onset speed versus swallowing because it bypasses some first-pass metabolism. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) But no validated data support specific percentage bioavailability or absorption time. --- 💊 Dosage Recommendations (Product-Based Only) Typical Dosing from Product Labels Capsules: 1–2 capsules, 1–2 times per day with meals. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][3]) Sublingual version: ~10 drops under the tongue twice daily. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) Course Duration: Usually 1 month, with optional repeated cycles. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][1]) There is no recognized “minimum effective dose” or “maximum safe dose” in pharmacological literature. --- ⚠️ Safety, Toxicity, and LD50 There is no published LD50 in humans or standardized animal toxicity data for Sigumir itself. Because it’s a peptide supplement derived from animal tissue, published acute toxicity values like LD50 are not available. In general, toxicity for peptides derived from natural tissue is low, but this cannot be used to infer safety across individuals. Some supplements suggest “well-tolerated with no side effects,” but this has no rigorous safety data backing it. ([Anti Aging Peptides][4]) Contraindications & Cautions Pregnant or breastfeeding women are typically advised not to use without medical supervision. ([Peptidi][5]) Individuals with allergies or intolerances should exercise caution. ([Peptidi][5]) --- 🛑 What We Cannot Provide (No Evidence Available) Due to the lack of credible pharmacology data: ❌ No half-life values ❌ No measured bioavailability percentages ❌ No receptor binding profiles ❌ No LD50 values for humans or animals beyond general peptide toxicity assumptions ❌ No standardized therapeutic index --- 📌 Summary | Parameter | Known / Unknown | | ----------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ | | Mechanism of Action | Proposed from product literature (support joint/cartilage) | | Half-Life | Unknown | | Bioavailability | Not quantified | | Minimum Effective Dose | Not clinically defined | | Maximum Safe Dose | Not clinically defined | | LD50 / Toxicity Threshold | Not determined in formal studies | --- ✅ Final Takeaway Sigumir should be regarded as a dietary supplement with claimed joint support properties, not as a pharmacologically characterized drug. There is no established pharmacokinetic or toxicology profile in the medical literature, so precise values like half-life, LD50, bioavailability, or safety ranges simply do not exist in the scientific record. If you want detailed clinical data or drug-like profiling, especially for research or medical purposes, you would need information from formal clinical pharmacology studies — which, to date, are not available for Sigumir. --- If you need, I can help you find published clinical studies on Sigumir or compare it with established cartilage-support drugs like glucosamine/chondroitin. title: Peptide Complex A 5
content: Here’s the most accurate, science-based summary possible of what peptide complex A-5 is and what is (and isn’t) known about its pharmacological actions, kinetics (half-life, bioavailability), dosages, and toxicity — based on credible research and verified product information. There is no reliable, peer-reviewed pharmacological data on “A-5 peptide complex” (as sold commercially) that provides detailed actions, half-lives, bioavailability, dose-response curves, LD50, or safety margins in humans. This answer clarifies what is documented versus what is claimed without robust evidence. --- 🧬 What Peptide Complex A-5 Actually Is Peptide complex A-5 (often marketed under names like “Cerluten” or “A-5 Cerluten”) is a dietary peptide supplement — not an approved drug — typically extracted from brain tissue of young animals (often calves) and sold as a peptide bioregulator. ([Qi Supplements][1]) It is often described by suppliers as a mix of short brain-derived peptides intended to support central nervous system functions. ([peptide-shop.com][2]) The composition and precise sequences of the peptides in A-5 are not disclosed in scientific literature or regulatory filings. No peer-reviewed pharmacology exists for this complex as a defined compound. It is classified and marketed as a nutritional/food supplement, not a pharmaceutical drug. This distinction matters for evidence standards and safety evaluation. --- ⚠️ Scientific Evidence vs. Product Claims ⚬ Scientific Evidence • Peer-reviewed research on “peptide bioregulators” in Russia suggests that short peptides can affect gene expression and protein synthesis in cells in experimental models. However, these studies are generally low-quality, mostly Russian reports, and not specific to A-5. ([PubMed][3]) • General literature on therapeutic peptides shows that peptides typically have short half-lives, limited oral bioavailability, and require parenteral routes for meaningful systemic exposure. ([PubMed][4]) ⚬ Product/Marketing Claims Peptide bioregulator sellers claim effects such as: improved brain metabolism and cognitive function, support for recovery after neurological injury, slowing of age-related decline. These claims are not supported by robust clinical trials in humans and are typical of nutritional supplement marketing. ([peptide-shop.com][2]) --- 🧪 Pharmacological Actions — What Is Known Because A-5 is not a defined drug molecule with known structure, we can’t give reliable specific pharmacodynamics like receptor targets or measurable effects. What can be said in general (from peptide biology): ✔ Short peptides can modulate: cellular protein synthesis, gene expression, cell regulatory processes in vitro and in some animal studies. But none of these have been demonstrated in rigorous human trials for A-5 specifically. ([PubMed][3]) ✔ There is no validated mechanism of action for A-5 in humans, e.g., binding to specific receptors or known neurotransmitter pathways. --- 📈 Pharmacokinetics — Half-Life & Bioavailability There is no published PK data for A-5, period. So we must rely on general peptide pharmacology: 🔹 Half-Life (general peptides) Unmodified peptides (<10 kDa) are rapidly degraded by proteases and cleared renally, often with half-lives from minutes to a few hours. ([PubMed][4]) 🔹 Bioavailability Peptides taken by mouth usually have very poor systemic bioavailability due to digestion. ([PubMed][4]) Possible routes and relative likelihood of absorption: Oral swallowed — typically ~0% (most are digested). Sublingual — may allow some direct mucosal absorption, but quantitative systemic absorption is unknown or negligible. Parenteral (e.g., IV, SC) — highest potential bioavailability but is not how A-5 is normally used. 📌 Key Point There’s no validated measurement of A-5’s half-life, Cmax, Tmax, or bioavailability in humans. --- 💊 Dosage & Safety 🟡 Common Product Dosage (Supplement Instructions) Sublingual: ~5–6 drops (~0.25–0.35 mL) 3–4 times daily (≈2.5–3.5 mg/day) for ~1 month. ([peptide-shop.com][2]) Capsules, when sold, often contain ~10 mg per capsule. ([eBay][5]) These are marketing recommendations, not clinical dose-responses. ⚠ Toxicity and Safety Data There are no high-quality clinical toxicity studies for A-5. No LD50 (lethal dose 50) is established in humans. No safety margins are scientifically defined. Because peptide extracts can vary and absorption is poorly understood, the concept of “safe range” versus “dangerous dose” cannot be reliably determined for A-5 specifically. --- 🧠 Summary — What You Can Truthfully Say | Category | Known | Not Known | | --------------------------------------- | ---------- | --------- | | Specific pharmacological actions of A-5 | ❌ | ❌ | | Mechanism of action | ❌ | ❌ | | Half-life in humans | ❌ | ❌ | | Bioavailability metrics | ❌ | ❌ | | Clinical dose-response | ❌ | ❌ | | Toxicity / LD50 data | ❌ | ❌ | | Use as supplement | ✔ marketed | — | In short: A-5 peptide complex as sold in supplements has no reliable, verifiable pharmacokinetic or pharmacodynamic data published in peer-reviewed scientific literature. Claims about effects are based on marketing, tradition, or low-quality studies, not validated biomedical research. --- 🧠 General Things Known About Peptide Drugs (for context) From the broader peptide drug class: Peptides generally have short half-lives due to enzymatic degradation. ([PubMed][4]) Oral bioavailability of peptides is typically very low without special formulation. ([PubMed][4]) Parenteral administration (IV/SC) increases systemic exposure. ([PubMed][4]) Clinical toxicity and LD50 values are established only for rigorously studied peptide drugs — not for unstandardized peptide supplements. ([PMC][6]) --- ⚡ Bottom Line Peptide complex A-5 is a marketed nutritional peptide supplement with no high-quality scientific data on its pharmacology, kinetics, or safety. Any specific numbers (half-life, bioavailability, dose thresholds, LD50) cannot be provided because they simply don’t exist in credible sources. If your intent is research or therapeutic understanding, the relevant peptides with detailed data are those in clinical development or approved peptide drugs — not commercial bioregulator complexes like A-5. --- If you want, I can help you compare A-5 to specific, well-studied therapeutic peptides that do have pharmacokinetic and dose-response data — just let me know. title: Peptide Complex A 6
content: Here is a comprehensive pharmacological profile for peptide complex A-6 — more properly known as A6 (also Å6), a short urokinase-derived octapeptide (sequence Ac-KPSSPPEE-NH₂) that has been studied as an antineoplastic/anti-metastatic agent and in early clinical trials. Note: A6 is a research and investigational compound — it is not an approved drug in most countries. ([cancer.gov][1]) --- 📌 1. Mechanism(s) of Pharmacological Action Primary actions identified in preclinical/clinical research: 1. Modulation of CD44 activity A6 binds to CD44 (a cell surface adhesion receptor), alters its conformation, inhibits tumor cell migration/invasion, and activates focal adhesion kinase (FAK) / MAPK signaling. ([PubMed][2]) 2. Anti-metastatic and anti-invasive effects A6 inhibits migration and metastasis of CD44-positive tumors in multiple models. ([PubMed][3]) 3. Anti-angiogenic properties Although less well quantified, A6 exhibited anti-angiogenic effects in early studies. ([PubMed][4]) 4. Anti-inflammatory and anti-osteoclast effects A6 attenuates LPS-induced osteoclastogenesis and bone destruction by modulating NF-κB, AMPK, and Akt pathways in macrophage/osteoclast models. ([PubMed][5]) 5. Cell signaling modulation The peptide has upstream effects on CD44-mediated pathways affecting adhesion, migration, and survival. ([PubMed][3]) --- 🕐 2. Pharmacokinetics (PK) Absorption & Time to Peak After subcutaneous (s.c.) administration in humans, time to peak plasma concentration (Tmax) ~ 0.5–2.1 hours. ([PubMed][4]) Half-Life (t½) In healthy human volunteers after s.c. injection, terminal half-life ~1.4–1.8 hours. ([PubMed][4]) Elimination A6 is eliminated largely unchanged in urine (~78–95% depending on dose and regimen). ([PubMed][4]) Bioavailability Exact absolute bioavailability values (especially oral) have not been published in peer-reviewed A6 human studies — but like most short peptides, A6 is likely poorly bioavailable orally unless modified (protease resistance, formulation strategies). In early human PK studies, only subcutaneous administration was evaluated. ([PubMed][4]) Oral route: Peptides like A6 are generally vulnerable to proteolytic digestion — unless specifically engineered for oral delivery, oral bioavailability is likely very low. Research exists exploring exceptions for other peptides but not specific quantification for A6. ([patents.google.com][6]) --- 💊 3. Dosage Information from Clinical Studies Human data exists only from early phase clinical trials: Subcutaneous Dosing (Human Phase I) Single doses: 15 mg up to 300 mg s.c. were safe and well-tolerated. ([PubMed][4]) Repeated s.c. dosing: Up to 150 mg every 12 hours for 6 days was tolerated. ([PubMed][4]) Clinical Oncology Trial Doses In a randomized Phase II trial (ovarian cancer), daily s.c. injections of 150 mg (low) and 300 mg (high) were used. ([PubMed][7]) Typical Research/Preclinical Doses (Animal Studies) Murine tumor and bone loss models often used ~50–100 mg/kg s.c. with biological effects reported. ([PubMed][2]) --- ⚠️ 4. Safety, Toxicity & Maximum Tolerated Dose Human Safety Observations No dose-limiting toxicity was observed in early Phase I trials up through 300 mg s.c. single dose. ([PubMed][4]) No early immunogenic response (anti-A6 antibodies) detected. ([PubMed][4]) Toxic Dose / LD₅₀ No published LD₅₀ values exist for humans or standard animal toxicology data in peer-reviewed literature for the native A6 peptide. As a short peptide with rapid elimination and no serious toxicity up to high doses in early human trials, its acute lethal dose is unknown, and toxicity thresholds are not defined. ⚠️ This means: LD₅₀ and toxicity curves are not established — and inferring them would be speculative and irresponsible. --- 📊 5. Summary Table | Parameter | Reported Value / Range | Notes | | ----------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------- | | Sequence | Ac-KPSSPPEE-NH₂ | 8-amino acid peptide derived from uPA. ([cancer.gov][1]) | | Mechanism of Action | CD44 modulation, anti-migration, anti-invasion, anti-angiogenic | Preclinical/clinical. ([PubMed][2]) | | Tmax (s.c.) | ~0.5–2.1 h | In healthy humans. ([PubMed][4]) | | T½ (terminal) | ~1.4–1.8 h | Rapid clearance. ([PubMed][4]) | | Bioavailability | Not established (likely low orally) | Only s.c. PK characterized. ([PubMed][4]) | | Human safe dose (single) | 15–300 mg s.c. | Phase I. ([PubMed][4]) | | Human safe dose (repeat) | Up to 150 mg s.c. every 12 h | Short term. ([PubMed][4]) | | Dose in Phase II cancer trial | 150–300 mg s.c. daily | Ovarian cancer. ([PubMed][7]) | | LD₅₀ (animal/human) | Not established | No public data. | | Oral bioavailability | Not characterized | Likely negligible unless modified. | --- ❗ Important Considerations & Limitations 🔹 No oral A6 PK data in humans — short peptides are generally poorly absorbed orally due to proteolysis. ([patents.google.com][6]) 🔹 Toxicology (LD₅₀, safety margins) are not published — clinical dosing tolerability is limited to early, controlled settings. ([PubMed][4]) 🔹 Mechanism details are primarily preclinical; clinical efficacy data are mixed and not definitive. ([PubMed][7]) 🔹 Quantitative dose–response curves (e.g., EC₅₀, IC₅₀ for individual pathways in humans) are not generally available beyond cell models. ([PubMed][2]) --- 📌 Summary A6 is a short peptide with anti-metastatic, anti-migratory, anti-angiogenic and anti-inflammatory potential acting mainly through CD44 modulation and related signaling pathways. It shows a short half-life (~1–2 h) after subcutaneous administration and rapid renal elimination. Human clinical data demonstrate safety up to hundreds of milligrams s.c., but oral administration, bioavailability, and toxicity thresholds (LD₅₀) are not established. ([PubMed][4]) If you want, I can help summarize typical preclinical dose–effect relationships (e.g., IC₅₀/EC₅₀ values for migration inhibition, signaling changes in cell models) in tabular form. Would you like that? [1]: https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-drug/def/urokinase-derived-peptide-a6?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Definition of urokinase-derived peptide A6 - NCI Drug Dictionary - NCI" [2]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21885863/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "A6 peptide activates CD44 adhesive activity, induces FAK and MEK phosphorylation, and inhibits the migration and metastasis of CD44-expressing cells - PubMed" [3]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25870596/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Modulation of CD44 Activity by A6-Peptide - PubMed" [4]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15176647/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous A6, an 8-amino acid peptide with anti-angiogenic properties, in healthy men - PubMed" [5]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28493442/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "uPA-derived peptide, Å6 is involved in the suppression of lipopolysaccaride-promoted inflammatory osteoclastogenesis and the resultant bone loss - PubMed" [6]: https://patents.google.com/patent/CA2583716A1/en?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Oral dosage formulations of protease resistant polypeptides" [7]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18760451/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "A phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of clinical activity and safety of subcutaneous A6 in women with asymptomatic CA125 progression after first-line chemotherapy of epithelial ovarian cancer - PubMed"

title: Peptide Complex A 7
content: I couldn’t find credible, detailed scientific or clinical pharmacological data on something called “peptide complex A-7” as a defined pharmacological agent in the published literature or regulatory sources. There is no recognized therapeutic peptide with that exact name in established research or drug databases; no published values for human pharmacological actions, half-life, bioavailability, dosages, LD₅₀, or safety thresholds were available in the searches I conducted. Here’s what the searches did reveal — which may help clarify what you might be referring to and what cannot be provided because of lack of data: --- 🧬 1. There is an investigational peptide known as A7R The A7R peptide is a short heptapeptide (7-amino-acid peptide) that binds to neuropilin-1 (NRP-1) and vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-2 (VEGFR2), blocking VEGF165-mediated angiogenesis in cancer models, and has been studied in experimental oncology for anti-angiogenic and tumor-targeting purposes. ([PMC][1]) Pharmacological actions reported in research (preclinical): Anti-angiogenic: competes with VEGF165 for NRP-1/VEGFR2 binding, reducing angiogenesis and tumor growth in animal models. ([PMC][1]) Tumor vasculature alteration: may “normalize” chaotic tumor blood vessels in some models. ([cell.com][2]) Key points: A7R’s effects are mechanistic/targeted (blocking growth factor signaling), not general systemic pharmacology. It is not an approved drug — characterization is limited to experimental models. 🛑 What is not available in the literature that you asked for: Half-life in blood or tissues Bioavailability via oral, intravenous, subcutaneous, or other routes Dosage regimens Minimum effective dose, safe range, maximum tolerated dose LD₅₀ or toxicity thresholds No controlled human or animal PK/PD studies with quantitative pharmacokinetic values are published for A7R. These parameters simply don’t exist in established literature for this peptide. --- ⚠️ 2. Other A-7 or A7-named peptides are different There are other research peptides with “A7” in their name but not the same thing: 🧪 7-amino-acid peptides (e.g., 7P) A 7-amino-acid sequence studied for anti-inflammatory effects in mouse asthma models (reduced Th2 cytokines, reduced airway hyperresponsiveness). ([PubMed][3]) This is a different sequence and was examined only in preclinical disease models. 🧬 A7-1 peptide in wound healing A synthetic peptide tested in mice for accelerating wound and skin graft healing, but no systemic pharmacokinetic or safety profile is available. ([link.springer.com][4]) None of these are standardized therapeutic agents with regulatory approval. --- 🧪 Why there’s no pharmacological profile available Peptides like A7R are studied mainly as experimental tools or targeting ligands in laboratory research: Peptides without modifications are rapidly degraded by proteases in blood and the digestive tract, leading to very short half-lives and poor oral bioavailability. This is a well-known issue for peptides generally. ([sciencedirect.com][5]) Detailed toxicology (LD₅₀), bioavailability, and dosage profiles are typically determined only in drug development programs under regulatory studies — these have not been published for A7R or “A-7” complexes. --- 🔍 General remarks on peptide pharmacology (relevant but not specific to A7R) Pharmacokinetic tendencies of small peptides: Half-life: Many unmodified peptides are cleared within minutes to a few hours in blood. ([peptiderecon.com][6]) Bioavailability: Oral: very poor due to gastric/intestinal degradation. ([sciencedirect.com][5]) Parenteral (e.g., IV or subcutaneous): higher systemic exposure, but still short unless engineered. ([peptiderecon.com][7]) These general rules explain why specific PK values for A7R aren’t published — its unmodified form likely would have very limited systemic bioavailability and a short half-life, but the exact values are not established. --- 🧫 Summary | Parameter | Data available? | Notes | | ---------------------------- | -------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------- | | Pharmacological actions | ✕ (for A-7 complex specifically) | Only A7R actions known in research | | Time-course/PK values | ✕ | No published half-life, Tmax, Cmax | | Bioavailability (oral/IV/SC) | ✕ | Not determined in literature | | Dosage & safe range | ✕ | No clinical dosing data | | Minimum effective dose | ✕ | Only context-dependent experimental doses | | LD₅₀ / toxicity | ✕ | No formal toxicity studies published | Conclusion: There is no complete pharmacological profile published for a “peptide complex A-7” that meets your requested depth. The closest relevant scientific subject — A7R peptide — is an experimental antiangiogenic peptide studied in preclinical cancer research, and quantitative pharmacokinetics/toxicology data aren’t available in the literature. ([PMC][1]) --- If you can provide more context — for example, whether “A-7” refers to a specific sequence, brand, research peptide, or therapeutic candidate you saw in a study — I might be able to help locate more targeted information or clarify terminology. title: Peptide Complex A 9
content: Here’s what is scientifically and reliably known about Pielotax — and, importantly, where no good pharmacological data exists. Based on available information, Pielotax is not an approved medication with established pharmacokinetics or toxicity values; rather it is marketed as a dietary supplement / peptide bioregulator containing a “kidney peptide complex A-9” with claimed effects on kidney tissue. ([pielotax.com][1]) --- 🧪 What Pielotax Is Pielotax® is described in product literature as a natural peptide bioregulator containing a complex of short peptides (peptide complex A-9) intended to support kidney and urinary system function. It is marketed for use in conditions like urolithiasis, renal insufficiency, chronic pyelonephritis, nephropathy, and cystitis, although it is not recognized as a regulated drug and most claims are not supported by published pharmacological studies in humans. ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][2]) Summary of proposed actions from product descriptions: Normalizes metabolism in kidney tissues Regulates urinary system function Supports repair and regeneration of kidney cells Helps maintain filtration and excretion processes These actions are reported in product marketing materials and supplement descriptions, not clinical pharmacology references. ([pielotax.com][1]) --- 📊 Pharmacological Actions — What Is Claimed Since Pielotax is not a regulated drug, there are no authoritative pharmacodynamics or pharmacokinetic data (e.g., receptor binding, enzyme inhibition) in recognized scientific literature like PubMed or drug databases. However, based on product marketing: Reported/claimed actions: Supports kidney tissue cell metabolism and protein synthesis Helps reduce levels of urea and uric acid in blood Improves filtration and elimination of waste products Promotes cellular repair/regeneration in renal tissue These are supplement claims with very limited or no scientific validation outside of proprietary clinical brochures. ([antiaging-systems.com][3]) There is one independent study (not directly about the marketed Pielotax product, but relevant to peptide complexes isolated from kidneys) showing that a polypeptide complex from calf kidneys can stimulate kidney cell proliferation and reduce apoptosis in rat kidney tissue cultures, which may correlate conceptually with peptide bioregulator claims — but this is very preliminary and not specific to the marketed Pielotax formulation. ([PubMed][4]) --- ⏱ Pharmacokinetic Data (Absorption, Half-Life, Bioavailability) There are no published pharmacokinetic studies (e.g., half-life, bioavailability) on Pielotax in humans or animals in scientific literature or official drug references. 💡 Why this matters: Peptide supplements often have very different absorption and metabolism compared with conventional drugs Oral peptides can be broken down in the gut before absorption unless specially formulated Sublingual administration (as in the lingual version) is claimed to bypass some first-pass metabolism, but no quantitative data supports this for Pielotax A-9. ([Qi Supplements][5]) 📌 Conclusion on pharmacokinetics: There are no trustworthy values for: Time to onset of action Time to peak concentration (Tmax) Half-life (t½) Absolute or relative bioavailability (oral or sublingual) Such data simply do not exist in peer-reviewed publications or regulatory dossiers for Pielotax. --- 💊 Dosage and Administration (Supplement Guidance) Because Pielotax is marketed as a dietary supplement, recommended usage comes from product literature, not clinical guidelines: Capsule form: Typically 1–2 capsules per day with meals Standard course: 1–3 months, may be repeated after a break Each capsule ~0.2 g contains ~10 mg of peptide complex A-9 Typical regimen ~10-30 mg/day depending on source ([Peptide store, iPept.com][6]) Lingual (sublingual) form: ~10 drops under the tongue twice daily Each 1 mL contains ~10 mg peptide complex A-9 Absorption claimed to be faster, but not scientifically quantified ([Peptide store, www.iPept.eu][7]) ⚠️ Important: These are supplement recommendations and marketing instructions, not medically validated dose-response relationships. --- 🚫 Toxicity, LD50, Safety Thresholds There are no established toxicology studies, LD₅₀ values, or safety margins for Pielotax in scientific literature, toxicology databases, or drug reference texts. No human clinical trials published with controlled safety data exist. Because: It is not a pharmaceutical drug It has no regulatory approval It lacks peer-reviewed pharmacology or toxicology data …there are no reliable estimates for: Minimum effective dose Maximum tolerated dose LD50 (lethal dose for 50% of subjects) Onset of toxicity thresholds If such values exist at all, they would only come from controlled toxicology studies — which have not been published publicly for Pielotax. --- 📌 Summary: What Is and Is Not Known | Category | Available Data? | Scientific Evidence? | | ---------------------------------------- | -------------------------- | -------------------------------- | | Pharmacological actions (mechanism) | No validated mechanism | ❌ Not established | | Half-life / pharmacokinetics | No data | ❌ | | Oral bioavailability | No data | ❌ | | Dosage guidance | Yes (supplement guidance) | ⚠ From marketing, not clinical | | Safety & toxicity thresholds (LD50, MTD) | None | ❌ | | Clinical efficacy | Limited supplement claims | ❌ Not validated | --- ⚠️ Important Notes 👉 Pielotax is a dietary supplement, not an approved prescription medication. 👉 Claims about kidney regeneration, peptide-driven gene expression, and long-term metabolic effects are not established in peer-reviewed human studies. 👉 Always consult a qualified healthcare professional before using supplements, especially if you have a known kidney condition or are taking medications. --- If you want, I can help you compare Pielotax with clinically studied peptides or ask about scientifically validated kidney-support therapies. [3]: https://www.antiaging-systems.com/articles/clinical-study-of-the-biologically-active-peptide-bioregulator-pielotax/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Report: Clinical study results of peptide bioregulator Pielotax" [4]: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26033601/?utmsource=chatgpt.com "Peptide Regulation of Cells Renewal Processes in Kidney ..."
